Melinda is 43 years old and lives in  Barangay Marobbob Amulung, Cagayan. She is married and while she doesn't have any children, she is generously supporting her niece who is getting her masters degree.

Melinda owns a village store. She sells snacks called pansit (a type of noodles).  Before she was able to put up her small store, she sold her goods around the village. With her store ready, she can now offer more commodities to meet the demands of her customers. She wants to further develop her business, so she is asking for a loan from KIVA lenders to provide business capital, amounting to PHP 23,000. She wants to buy more goods to sell in her store to increase her profits.

Melinda hopes that her business will further expand so that she will be able to cover her own expenses and finance the schooling of her niece.

loans.use: Capital to buy more goods to sell in her general store

loans.name: Judith

texts.es:
Judith, de 27 años, es una joven muy alegre y trabajadora, vive en la casa de sus padres, a quienes desea ayudar con los gastos del hogar, aunque para eso tenga que trabajar muy duro.

Desde muy joven se dio cuenta que tenía que ayudar en las labores de su hogar para que su familia pueda tener una mejor economía. Con muchos sacrificios sus padres pudieron pagar todos sus estudios universitarios y ahora ella ha conseguido trabajo como nutricionista, pero su trabajo no ha hecho que deje de apoyar a sus padres, es por eso que los fines de semana sale a vender la leche que producen las vacas de sus padres a los distintos mercados de la ciudad, para que su familia pueda tener un ingreso extra.
Judith disfruta mucho realizando esta actividad, ya que siente que de esta manera aporta al desarrollo de su familia, lleva 7 años haciendo esto y considera que lo más difícil es tener que caminar por las calles de la ciudad en busca de clientes. Para más adelante, desea juntar el dinero necesario para implementar una tienda de abarrotes en su casa, la cual genere un ingreso económico para su familia.

Es el tercer préstamo de Judith con MFP, sabe que este dinero le ayudará mucho en su trabajo, pero también tiene presente que tiene que pagarlo a tiempo, para no meter en problemas a su banco comunal. Con los dos mil soles solicitados comprará más y mejores alimentos para sus vacas, porque sabe que su negocio depende de ellas.
texts.en:
Judith is 27 years old and she is a very happy and hard-working young woman. She lives with her parents and she wishes to help them with the household expenses, even though she will have to work very hard to this end.

Since she was very young she noticed that she needed to help out in her house so that her family will enjoy a better economy. Through great sacrifice her parents were able to cover all of her university tuition and now she has gainful employment as a nutritionist. But her work has not taken her away from helping her parents, so an extra source of income she goes to the difference markets of the city on the weekends to sell milk from their cows.

Judith loves her business, especially because she is contributing to the support of her family. She has been carrying out her business for the past 7 years, stating that the most difficult part is to have to walk through the streets of the city looking for clients. In the future she hopes to have saved enough money to set up a store from her home, in order to generate an income for her family.

This is Judith’s third loan through MFP (Kiva Field Partner), and she knows that this support will help her a great deal with her work. She is also very conscious of making payments on time, so that she will not put the community bank into a difficult situation. With the two thousand soles she will purchase more and better feed for her dairy cows, knowing that her business depends on them.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase feed for her dairy cows.

loans.name: Mr. Ny Say Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of fifteen people, is located in Khmot village in Kandal province and each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mr. Ny S. is the village bank president.

Mr. Ny S. is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which he grows rice. In this farming activity he now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to fix the water pump to irrigate the rice field. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy one and he will use the rest of the loan to buy more hose to water his field.

Mr. Ny S. is 47 years old and the father of four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because this child is only five years old. Mr. Ny S.’s wife, Mrs. DU. Yong, is employed in a garment factory.

Mrs. Kemla ChU., Mrs. Samoen M., and Mrs. Seryrin M. did not come to take their loans but their husbands did, so they are shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a water pump and some hose to irrigate his field

loans.name: Pompeo

texts.en:
Pompeo S. is 41 years old. His family lives in Barangay Marobbob Amulung,Cagayan. He is happily married to Alice who is a public school principal in their community. They are blessed with three children: Olive,13, Mary-joy,11,and Luis, 10. 
Pompeo and his wife decided to invest into a junk shop business which they are now managing together. They collect and buy scrap materials like old newspaper, used bottles, metal, plastic bottles, old boxes etc. and sell those to bigger enterprises. With the desire to expand their business, they have decided to request a loan from the KIVA lenders amounting to Php7,000 for additional working capital. Despite the financial crisis they are encountering in their business, Pompeo believes that with their strong faith in God they will succeed.

loans.use: Additional capital for his junk shop business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Luzmila

texts.es:
Luzmila, de 19 años, es una joven madre muy trabajadora, vive en la casa de uno de sus familiares junto a su esposo Rómulo de 20 años, con quien hace sólo unos días acaba de tener su primer hijo, al cual desea dar una buena vida.

Junto a su inseparable triciclo, sale todas las mañanas a vender fruta al mercado Santa Bárbara (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), es una joven muy carismática y alegre, motivo por el cual sus clientes prefieren comprarle a ella, además que la fruta que vende es muy fresca y tiene un aroma muy agradable.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas de venta, ya que de esta forma hace sus largas jornadas de trabajo más amenas. Lleva 3 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer bajo el intenso sol todo el día. 
Con el tiempo, espera tener un puesto en el mercado donde pueda vender con más tranquilidad sus productos.

Este es el primer préstamo de Luzmila con MFP, y está dispuesta a pagarlo por completo para acceder a uno nuevo, confía plenamente en las socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy querida. Con los mil soles solicitados comprará más fruta para surtir de mejor su triciclo y así ofrecer una mayor variedad a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Luzmila, 19, is a hard-working young mother. She lives in the house of one of her family members together with her 20 year old husband, Rómulo. Just a few days ago they had their first child, and they want to give him a good life. Together with her inseparable tricycle, she leaves every morning to sell fruit in the Santa Bárbara market (an important market in the city of Juliaca). She is a very charismatic and happy young woman. This motivates her customers, who prefer to buy from her. Also, the fruit she sells is very fresh, and it has a very pleasant aroma. What she likes best about her work is talking with her neighboring sales people. This makes her long work days more enjoyable. She has been doing this for three years. The most difficult part is having to stay under the intense sun the whole day. In time, she hopes to have a stand in the market where she can sell her products more calmly. This is Luzmila’s first loan with MFP. She is prepared to pay it back completely in order to have access to a new one. She completely trusts her colleagues in her communal bank, where she is much loved. She will use the 1,000 PEN to buy more fruit to better stock her tricycle and offer a greater variety to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Lelia

texts.en:
Lelia D. is from the village of Opol , Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old. Lelia is married and has 4 adult-age children. To make a living, Lelia owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Lelia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Lelia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve andexpand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Salve

texts.en:
Salve B., 42 years old, manages her village store which is situated in her house. Though she is busy managing her business, she is very proud because her family has a harmonious relationship. She is happily married to Manuel and they are blessed with five children: Melinda- 19 years of age, college level; Maryjane -17 years of age, first year college student taking up Education; Marife- 14 years of age, a sophomore high school student; Melvin- 11 years of age, a grade- VI  pupil and Mark Paul- 4 years of age. Their family resides in the Barangay of Marobbob Amulung,Cagayan.

Wanting to support the education of her children, Salve wants to make her variety store more productive; thus, she is requesting a loan of Php10,000 from KIVA lenders for the expansion of her business. With the loan, Salve will purchase more merchandise such as soft drinks and canned goods.

loans.use: For additional capital to buy soft drinks and canned goods for her store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria, D. 51 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora y solidaria. Vive en su casa propia junto a su menor hija, Elizabeth D. 10 años, y lo que más desea es tener una buena vida.

Los tejidos artesanales que realiza son muy novedosos y llamativos, ella los venD. en el puesto que tiene en la explanada “Laguna Temporal” (lugar donD. se realizan ferias en la ciudad D. Juliaca); sus clientes prefieren comprarle porque ofrece muy buenos precios, además que es una vendedora muy carismática y persuasiva.
Lo que más le gusta D. su trabajo es tejer, es por eso que siempre hace modelos novedosos, lleva 10  años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tejer los Chullos (prenda D. vestir para la cabeza), que son lo que más se venden a los turistas.
Para más adelante, espera poner una tienda más granD. donD. pueda vender sus tejidos.

Maria se encuentra en su tercer préstamo con MFP y está dispuesta a pagar sin demora sus cuotas, para no perjudicarse y no meter en problemas a sus compañeras. Con los mil doscientos soles solicitados comprará más lana para producir más tejidos artesanales.
texts.en:
Maria, 51, is a very hard-working and supportive woman. She lives in her own house with her youngest daughter, ten year old Elizabeth. What she wants most of all is to have a good life. The knitted handicrafts that she makes are very original and striking. She sells them in a stand that she has in the Laguna Temporal esplanaD. (place where they have fairs in the city of Juliaca). Her customers prefer to buy from her because she offers very good prices. Also, she is a charismatic and persuasive saleswoman. What she likes best about her work is knitting. That is why she always makes original things. She has been doing this for ten years. The most difficult part is knitting the “Chullos” (article of clothing for the head), which is what she sells the most of to the tourists. Later, she hopes to have a larger store where she could sell her knitting. This is Maria’s third loan with MFP. She is prepared to make her payments on time. She does not want to harm or cause problems for her colleagues. She will use the 1,200 PEN that she is asking for to buy more wool to make her knitted handicrafts.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wool

loans.name: Meiramhan's Group

texts.en:
Meiramhan T. is the leader of this group. She is fifty five years old. There are three children in her family.  Only their little twelve year old son lives with his parents. The eldest daughter, 35, is married and lives apart from her parents. Meiramhan’s middle daughter, 24, is married as well. She has moved to Kazakhstan. To support the family, Meiramhan’s husband works at the construction site in Bishkek, whereas Meiramhan raises cattle. Nobody really helped her start doing this. It was just her skill and curiosity.  Moreover, raising cattle has been bringing them enough income for Meiramhan to recently started repairing her house. Generally speaking, Meiramhan started animal husbandry quite late, as she was already in her mid – forties. Nevertheless, she has now ten years  experience in breeding cattle and a stable monthly income of $115. She has broken all the stereotypes of age and prejudices and thus has been an excellent example of an entrepreneur for  others. Meiramhan hopes to get a loan and buy a milk cow so that she is able to sell more milk. She has  plans to increase the number of cattle and to expand her business. 

Meiramhan’s partners are: Munara, Tatiana and Kulsumbubu.

Munara, 50, has raised three children. Her husband is a truck driver. Munara sells milk and raises cattle. She learned this occupation from her parents. Munara wants to open a shop with the profits she earns from selling milk. Munara needs a loan to buy a cow to sell more milk.

Tatiana, 30, is a mother of two daughters. Her children are very little, four and two years old respectively. Tatiana’s husband is a taxi driver. Tatiana is engaged in coal delivery. She needs a loan to buy a car for her work.

Kulsumbubu, 53, has two children. Her husband has left for Kazakhstan to work in construction. 
Kulsumbubu trades in cattle at the cattle market. Kulsumbubu needs a loan to invest  in purchasing sheep. 
 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a milk cow to sell more milk

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan S. is a 30-year-old married mother who currently lives in the territory of Kampong Chhnang, Cambodia. Chan S. is married and blessed with two children. She is a local rice farmer who learned this business from her grandparents. Her husband currently works with her on the farm.  Chan S. will be using her first loan in order to purchase a motorcycle which will allow her and her family to commute to the fields and to town.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle which will allow her and her family to commute to the fields and to town.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is a native of Cagayan. She is 49 years old and married to Alfonso B. Jr. who is a local farmer in their village. They are blessed with seven children. Four of the children are married and the others are still studying in a local school in their village.
Cristina manages her mini-grocery store in their community with her husband in order to provide a good education for their children.
She alternates her household activities with retail trade. She needs to be patient to use her time to be able to provide the needs of her family, especially when it comes to their educational needs.  She buys her commodities in Mariton, Tuguegarao, Cagayan once a month.
According to her, she has been in business for over ten years and she tries to maintain it for the sake of her children. Cristina is requesting a loan of Php15,000 from KIVA lenders for the maintenance and continuous development of her business. She hopes that her business will be supported by KIVA lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her mini-grocery business

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina R. is from the village of Grace Village, Sto. Nino, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Regina is married and has eight adult children. To make a living, Regina owns & operates a specialized retail business buying and selling rice in the local community. Regina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Regina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Regina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Regina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Publio

texts.es:
Publio tiene 32 años, él es una persona muy alegre y trabajadora, vive en la casa de sus padres donde ha implementado su taller textil, y su mayor anhelo es salir adelante en la vida.

Su vivienda está ubicada en una de las calles más céntricas de la ciudad de Juliaca, con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación pudo acondicionar un espacio para su negocio, el cual ahora le genera los ingresos necesarios para mantenerse. Él es un sastre muy hábil, por lo cual siempre tiene clientes a quienes confeccionarles un buen terno.
Lo que más le gusta de su actividad es observar el termino de su trabajo y ver como con mucho empeño puede crear una pieza de vestir de muy buena calidad, lleva 5 años en este negocio y considera que lo más difícil es cortar la tela sin equivocarse, ya que cualquiera fallo de su pulso podría malograr toda una jornada de trabajo y costarle mucho dinero. 
Para el futuro, espera tener una sastrería más grande donde pueda brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.

Este es el tercer préstamo de Publio con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo y está dispuesto a hacerlo. En su banco comunal es un socio muy responsable y solidario. Con los dos mil soles solicitados comprará una máquina para remallar y así mejorar el trabajo que realiza.
texts.en:
Publio, 32, is a very happy and hard-working person. He lives in his parents’ house, where he has set up his textile shop. His greatest desire is to get ahead in life. His house is located on one of the most central streets in the city of Juliaca. With great effort and dedication, he was able to equip a space for his business. His business now generates the necessary income to support himself. He is a very able tailor. Therefore, he always has customers to make a good suit for. What he likes best is seeing the end of his work and seeing how, with much effort, he can create an article of clothing of very good quality. He has been in this business for five years. The most difficult part is cutting the fabric without making a mistake. Any slight error could ruin a whole day’s work and cost him a lot of money. In the future he hopes to have a larger tailor’s shop, where he could offer better service to his customers. This is Publio’s third loan with MFP. He knows that he has to make all of his payments on time, and he is prepared to do so. He is a very responsible and supportive member in his communal bank. He will use the 2,000 PEN that he is requesting to buy a sewing machine and improve the work he does.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis P. is 33 years old and married to Lailanie, an Overseas Filipino Worker in Syria. The couple has been married for almost eight years now and has been blessed with two loving kids. Lei Ann is seven years old and Francis is two years old. They are three family members living together at the village of Ramona. He has had a hog-raising business for almost two years. His net income, when he sells one hog is Php 1,500. Aside from hog raising, he also has a part-time job selling fluorescent Philips light bulbs. He desires a loan of Php 7,000, which he will use to purchase some hog feed and a hog to raise. He is thankful to those lenders who reach out to him, especially in times of needs.

loans.use: To buy hog feed and some hogs to raise

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina C. is from the village of Lupagan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old, is widowed, and has three adult children. Lina owns and operates a business providing rooms to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Lina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 33,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for the renovation of her rooms. Lina is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to complete the renovation of her rooms. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To complete the renovation of her rooms

loans.name: Saret

texts.en: Mrs. Saret S. is a villager in Spueu village in Takeo province. She is 28 years old and the mother of two children, who are all too young to work or study. Mrs. Saret Surem is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Toem Sary, is a cow middleman. Mrs. Saret S. is requesting a loan to purchase a cow for reselling. This will improve their income.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Romana

texts.en:
This is Romana A., a 42-year-old entrepreneur from Maricaban, Pasay City.  She currently lives with her three children. Two of her children are in college and the eldest is already working.  Her husband Rene, 56, is a seafarer so he is always out of the country.

Romana has been managing their pedicab (rickshaw) transport business for four years now, along with selling frozen meat products (sausages, hotdogs, hams, etc.) she gets from a prominent dealer.  However, her refrigerator was damaged by the recent flood that hit the entire Manila area, so she has to stop her frozen meat products business for a while because she has nowhere to store her products.  Then she got a loan from the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in the amount of P17,000.00, which she used to start a small sari-sari (general) store.  She now earns more than P10,000.00 a month from the combined earnings of her new business and her earnings from the rickshaw.

She is working hard to be able to get back her former sources of income.  When her children finish their college education and are able to get decent jobs, Romana wants to go back to the province and stay there for good.  Currently, Romana has requested a new loan from CCT in the amount of P20, 000.00 to infuse more capital into her new general store. 

  

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for general store

loans.name: Rebeca

texts.es:
Rebeca, de 44 años, es una mujer muy sencilla y alegre, vive es su casa propia y lo que más desea es tener una mejor calidad de vida.

Su tienda de abarrotes es una de las más visitadas en su barrio “Villa el Paraíso”, desde muy temprano por la mañana abre su local en espera de que sus clientes lleguen a comprar los comestibles que necesitan. Ella es una vendedora muy alegre y atenta, ya que siempre recibe a sus clientes con una sonrisa y está dispuesta ayudarlos en sus compras.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus clientes, lleva 8 años en este negocio y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día dentro de su tienda sin poder salir. 
Para más adelante, espera poder hacer ampliar su tienda y llenarla de más mercadería, para poder ofrecer a sus clientes una mejor variedad de productos.

Es el cuarto préstamo de Rebeca con MFP y está dispuesta a pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, ya que no quiere causarle problemas a su banco comunal, donde es muy querida por el resto de sus compañeras. Con los seiscientos soles solicitados comprará más productos para surtir mejor su tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Rebecca, 44, is a very unassuming and happy woman. She lives in her own house. What she wants most of all is to have a better quality of life. Her grocery store is one of the most frequented stores in her neighborhood, Villa el Paraíso. She opens her store very early in the morning waiting for her customers to come and buy the food they need. She is a happy and attentive saleswoman. She always greets her customers with a smile, and she is always ready to help them with their purchases. What she likes best about her work is talking with her customers. She has been in this business for eight years. The most difficult part is staying in her store all day without being able to leave. Later, she hopes to be able to expand her store and fill it with more merchandise. This way she will be able to offer her customers a better variety of products. This is Rebeca’s fourth loan with MFP. She is prepared to make all of her payments on time because she does not want to cause problems for her communal bank. She is much loved by her colleagues. She will use the 600 PEN she is requesting to buy more products to better stock her grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe E. is from the village of Grace Village, Sto. Nino, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 32 years old. Fe is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Fe owns & operates a specialized retail business buying and selling of rice in the local community. Fe has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,800 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Fe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Thea

texts.en: Mrs. Thea P. is a villager in Ta Sman village in Takeo province. She is 30-years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are in school. She and her husband, Mr. Den Sa Em, are farmers who own a 1-hectar field of land where they cultivate rice. Although this couple tries to work hard, they do not earn enough income to support their family. Mrs. Thea P. is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding and fertilizers to support the rice field. This will help them increase their income and make their labor more productive.

loans.use: To purchase a breeding cow and fertilizers

loans.name: Saom's Group

texts.en: This group consists of three low-income people who have decided to request a loan, which they will use for various purposes. Mrs. Saom S. is 39 years of age and has been selected to be the leader of the loan group. She was married, but divorced her husband, and she has no children. To earn a living, Saom has owned a small grocery business since early 2008. The store is located in the market, and she earns approximately $3 a day from selling grocery goods. Saom said that her trade is going very well and she is attracting many customers. She hopes to meet the demands of her customers by using the loan from Kiva to pruchase more grocery inventory to sell. The other borrowers are Mrs. D., a grocery vendor who is asking for a loan to buy more items to sell, and Mrs. S., a cake seller who is requesting a loan to buy ingredients to make cakes.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery inventory to sell

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella M., 56, has been in business for three decades now. Her husband Angelo ably assists her in tending her business along with their two adult-aged children. This cooperative family lives in Maricaban, Pasay City. Estrella owns and manages a sari-sari (general) store and has recently added a food stall within her general store. She also sells rice to her neighbors. She earns P36, 000.00 a month, which has allowed her to hire two store/kitchen assistants. Beef and chicken porridge is her specialty. Estrella’s day starts very early; she and her husband wake up at dawn to prepare food ingredients.

She is happy to have been among the pioneer members of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2001. The loans provided by the cooperative, with its low interest rates, have helped her improve her family’s economic condition through the earnings of her store. Estrella's profits were also helpful in setting up her newest venture – the mini-eatery (food stall). Estrella is now in need of fresh loan in the amount of P10, 000.00 to better improve her food stall. She will buy large pots, kitchen utensils and an additional gas stove. She hopes her business will soon grow to become a restaurant.    
  
About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase large pots, utensils and a gas stove

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Mr. Ven N. is a villager in Thnuoh village in Takeo province.  Mr. Ven N. is 55-years old. He and his wife have five children, two work in a garment factory, one is a farmer, and the other two are enrolled in the local school. He owns a poultry business, and his wife, Mrs. Non Srey, is a farmer who owns a small plot of land where she cultivates rice. She is requesting a loan to buy 500 ducks and duck food for breeding for the poultry business. This will expand the business and increase their income.

loans.use: To purchase 500 ducks for breeding and duck food

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie S. is from the village of  Casinglot, Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old, married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosemarie owns and operates a business venture a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosemarie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosemarie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth M. is from the village of Grace Village, Sto. Nino, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 54 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthorn N. is a villager in the village of Trapeang Srangae in Takeo Province. She is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more grocery products to sell. Her husband, Mr. Maen Chan, uses electricity to charge a battery for income. Mrs. Chanthorn N. is 42 years old and the mother of four children. One of her children is working in a garment factory, while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to sell

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario T. is 49 years old and has been a businesswoman for years. She is married to Alfredo, 52, who drives a motorized tricycle for a living.  Two of their three children are now working and the youngest remains in grade school. This happy family lives in Maricaban, Pasay City.

For nine years now, Rosario has been buying and selling small basic household items, including decorated candles, dishwashing solutions, fabric conditioners and even diapers. She earns more than P12, 000.00 a month and even more when there is increased demand for her items, such as for her candles during All Saints’ Day, which is observed countrywide. She’s happy that her earnings can augment her husband’s income to help with their family’s daily needs.

Rosario is among the pioneer members of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative who joined in the summer of 2002. She has just finished repaying a previous loan of P32,000.00 from the cooperative and is now asking for a new loan of P35,000.00 as additional capital for the continued growth of her business. She wishes to improve her business to be able to have an abundant life with her family.      


About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for business growth

loans.name: Jamilya's Group

texts.en:
Jamilya is the leader of this group. She is fifty-one years old. Jamilya has raised four children and has been divorced for some years. Her children have already grown up. Her eldest daughter, 31, is married. Her eldest and middle sons, 23 and 21 respectively, are both married. Jamilya’s youngest daughter is 17. Her sons and her daughter live with her. To make a living, Jamilya and her sons are trade in cattle. Being an experienced business-woman, Jamilya has been saving her earnings in order to find something in which to invest. Seven years ago, Jamilya was able to buy a calf with her savings, and she began a breeding business. Since that time, she has been able to increase her cattle population. She has started trading these cattle. As her sons grew up, she involved them in her business and they have become her partners. Her $95 investment, seven years ago, has brought an income of $190 per month. They recently were able to buy a car, Audi 100, for her eldest son. Jamilya needs a loan to invest in purchasing calves for feeding. Once she earns the money from selling these calves, she plans to make a repair at her house.
Despite her age, Jamilya is full of energy to keep working. She wants to build a big shed for her cattle and to help her son purchase accommodation as capital investment. 
 
Jamilya’s partners are: Ulan, Nazira and Elmira.

Ulan, 26, is single. His occupation is animal husbandry and he trades in hay. Ulan has been quite successful in this business as he has been able to start building himself a house. He has applied for this loan to purchase some cattle. 

Nazira, 26, has two children. She breeds poultry: geese, ducks and hens. During one year, she has experience and a stable income. Nazira hopes to get this loan in order to purchase laying hens and broilers. 

Elmira, 44, is a mother of three children. With her husband, she brings calves from pastures and sells them in cattle market. Elmira needs this loan to buy calves.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy calves for feeding and later resale.

loans.name: Phally

texts.en: Mrs. Phally C. is a villager in the village of Angk Roneab in Takeo Province. She is a farmer, and she is also a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it. She is requesting a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Meng Samin, is a taxi driver who can make a small income to support the family. Mrs. Phally C. is 42 years old and the mother of six children. Her children all attend the local school. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets for breeding

loans.name: Ma

texts.en: Ma V. is a 55-year-old farmer and mother. She is widowed and blessed with one daughter. Her daughter is married and employed in a garment factory. Ma V. is applying for capital to buy rice in bulk to store. She will sell the rice when it commands the highest price.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk to store her stock supply.

loans.name: Melonie

texts.en:
Melonie gives her best to become a responsible mother to her three children. She strives hard to reach her goal, when it comes to business.  She sells vegetables, fruits, and other foods with the use of her motorcycle. She goes to different villages to sell. Her daily net income is PHP 200, but her income is not sufficient to maintain her business. She is requesting a loan, in the amount of PHP 10,000, to purchase more commodities to sell. 
She was married to Francisco, but their marriage lasted for only eight years. They were blessed with three children: Melody, 14, second year high school; Angelica, 12, grade six level, and Francesca, eight years old, grade three level. She lives, with her children at the village of Ramona, Angadanan, Isabela. Melonie says that she can raise her children alone and face any trial that comes to her life.

loans.use: To purchase more commodities to sell.

loans.name: Edelina

texts.en:
Edelina F. is married to a public utility worker in the municipality and they raise three children who are all enrolled in a public high school.

Edelina is the owner of a small restaurant. Her business is located in Poblacion, Leon B. Postigo where motor-cab drivers and some passengers stop to obtain their food. During weekends, Edelina’s three children assist her in manning the business. She has been operating her small restaurant for almost four years and it proves to be a great help in generating additional income to support her family.

Edelina is currently utilizing her third loan and she is very hopeful that this loan will help in developing her business venture.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her restaurant

location.town: Poblacion, Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga Del Norte

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
Luciana B. is from the village of Grace Village, Sto. Nino, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 61 years old. Luciana is married and has 9 adult children. Luciana raises livestock to make her living. Her business involves buying and raising pigs for sale. Luciana has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luciana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Luciana is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Luciana from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: Sarou

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarou S. lives in Thnuoh village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 0.5-hectare (1.25-acre) piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Aside from this farming activity, she also raises pigs.

Now, while her business is going well, Mrs. Sarou S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a piglet to raise and some pig food. 

Mrs. Sarou S. is 26 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Bon Kosal, is a construction worker who is able to make a small income to support the family. Her husband and child are shown with her in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a piglet to raise and pig food

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is 53 years old and she has been engaged in a hog raising business for almost ten years. Her net income, when she sells one hog is PHP 2,500. She is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000, that she will use to purchase hog feeds.
Thelma is married to Jaime P., who works as a farmer. They are blessed with four children, three boys and one girl. Two of her children are already married and the other two are still single. Their house is  downstream, near an irrigation canal. Thelma hopes that lenders will grant her requested loan. She hopes to have a fruitful income to be able to pay for the medication of her daughter who is mentally ill.

loans.use: Additional investment in her livestock business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth Loechico is a 44-year old beauty salon owner from Malibay, Pasay City.  Her husband, Ramon, 49, works for a funeral parlor. They have four children; one of whom is in college, and two are in high school.

Elizabeth has been in the beauty salon business for fifteen years.  She likes the idea of making people physically beautiful. She gets tired at the end of the day, especially in peak season.  She says she can’t afford to hire help at the moment because her salon is just too small.  But, small as it is, she earns PHP 25, 000.00 a month.  Her profits go to the education of her children as well as to the family’s basic daily needs.

In 2003, she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  She has recently applied for a new loan in the amount of PHP 42, 000.00.  She will use the funds to purchase supplies for her parlor/salon. 

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for the beauty salon.

loans.name: Samnang

texts.en: Mrs. Samnang C. lives in the village of Samchat Thnuoh in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land for cultivating rice. Her husband, Mr. Siek La, is a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it. Mrs. Samnang C. is requesting a loan to buy piglets for breeding and to build a piggery for breeding pigs. She is 42 years old and the mother of four children. Three of her children are enrolled in the local school. Her youngest child is too young to work or study, because this child is only two years old. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding and to build a piggery for breeding pigs

loans.name: Marialita

texts.en: Marialita G. is from the village of Katipunan, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Marialita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Marialita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marialita is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.en:
Felicidad R. is 59 years old, living in the Barangay Marobbob Amulung,Cagayan. She is married to Catalino, 62 years old, a local farmer in their community. They are blessed with six grown up children. All of her children are married and live independently.
Felicidad is very proud to have responsible, hardworking children. Felicidad operates her general store in their village. She sells a variety of goods and groceries including vegetables, candies, bread, canned goods, cooking ingredients and household tools. Much of their income goes towards their daily basic needs.
Felicidad is requesting a loan from the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP 7,000 to support her general store.
Felicidad will be very grateful if the loan is granted because it will help her family and her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for her store.

loans.name: Pedra

texts.en:
Pedra S. is from the village of Grace Village, Sto. Nino, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 56 years old. Pedra is married and has 1 school-aged child. Pedra sells snacks & other delicacies in the local community to make a living. Pedra has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2009, Pedra joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Pedra is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she has for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Pedra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make and sell food products.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en: Mrs. Jessica N. is from the town of Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old, is separated, and has only one school-aged child. Jessica owns and operates a business selling herbal products in the local community and earns Php 6,000 monthly net income from her business. In 2007, Jessica joined PMPC to gain access to its programs and services. Currently, she's obtaining her 4th loan in the amount of Php 25,000 which will be used as additional capital for her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Im N. is a 30-year-old farmer who lives in Kampong Chhnang Province. Besides her farm work, Im N. also sells fresh fish that she gets from her husband's fishing. This couple has two school-aged children. They live together in a medium sized home. Im N. thinks that the fishing business is the profitable part of their current family income. Im N. requests a loan to buy more nets and traps to supply her husband’s fishing business.

loans.use: To buy more nets and traps to supply her husband’s fishing business.

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Mr. Kun E. lives in Samchat village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a pig breeder. He is applying for a loan to buy piglets for breeding since his business is doing well. 

His wife, Mrs. Chea Chantha, helps him in his current business. This couple has three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, and the other two are attending the local school. His wife is shown in the picture with him.

loans.use: to buy piglets for breeding

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn B. is from the village of San Isidro,  Talakag Bukidnon. She is 30 years old. Arlyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. Arlyn runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells both food & daily use products in the local community. Arlyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Arlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Arlyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Arlyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
At the age of 38, Violeta C. has been engaged in retail vending for almost 10 years. Her daily net income is 150 Philippine pesos, which she utilizes for her family's daily needs. Wanting to purchase more grocery items, she decided to borrow from Kiva lenders a loan of php20,000. She hopes lenders will reach out for her and support her business for it to develop into a much better and more profitable store.

Violeta is married to Danilo, who manages their farm lot. The couple is blessed with three children: Elic, 18, a second-year college student; Emeliza, 15, a fourth-year high school student; and Erika, 8, a grade three student. She wants to expand her business to increase her income to be able to support the schooling of her children.

loans.use: Additional capital for her retail store

loans.name: Borey

texts.en: Mrs. Borey B. lives in Samchat village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Mrs. Borey B. has decided to ask for a loan to buy pig food for her breeding business since it is doing well. She is 33 years old and a widow without any children.

loans.use: to buy pig food for her breeding

loans.name: Sreu

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreu L. lives in Samchat village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chhoem Seng, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. They have a child who is a guard who can make a small income to support the family. 

Although this family works hard, they still earn less income than they need to cover their expenses and they do not have enough money to buy a motorbike. Thus, Mrs. Sreu L. is requesting a loan to add to her savings with which to buy a motorbike for the family's use. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the family's use

loans.name: Phon

texts.en:
Mr. Phon P. lives in Krang Roungu village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which he cultivates rice. Aside from this farming activity, he is also an ice-cream seller.

Mr. Phon P. is a widower with three children: one is working in a garment factory, another is working in Thailand, and the youngest one is attending the local school.

Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than needed to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mr. Phon P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a calf to raise and he hopes to improve their living conditions after he sells the grown animal.

loans.use: To buy a calf to raise

loans.name: Pampilo

texts.en:
This is Pampilo I., who is 59 years old.  He is married to Lydia, 48. They have three children: one is in college, the eldest is working and the other stays home.

Pampilo owns and manages a home-based manufacturing business. He makes snack items like banana chips, sweetened puffed corn and fish crackers. He hires an assistant in the work yard.  He earns close to 30,000 Philippine pesos a month. He is happy that one of his children has already finished college and another one is working his way towards graduation. He was also able to purchase property in the province. All these are fruits of his labor.    

Pampilo became an active member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005 and has since been enjoying many benefits from the cooperative. He is currently in need of additional capital for the continuity of his business. He applied for a P30,000 loan with CCT to augment his business needs.

He wishes for his small manufacturing station to become a factory soon.  He’s working double time nowadays because he still has two children to get through college.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social-development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for the production of chips and crackers

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
Sou O. is a married woman who has given birth to five children. One of them is married and working, while the other four attend the local school and are dependent on Sou O.'s income. Sou O. and her husband always wake up when the sky is still dark in order to buy fish from fishermen who live along the river, and then they bring their fish to sell at the market. This couple normally generates $5 of profit a day to help manage what their family needs. 

Sou O. faces an obstacle with transporting her fish to the market because her existing motorcycle is too old and has broken frequently. To solve the problem, she would like to request a loan to replace her old motorbike.   

(Note: Sou O.'s husband is pictured here.)

loans.use: To replace her old motorbike

loans.name: Ren

texts.en: Mrs. Ren K. is a resident of Krang Roung village in Takeo province. She owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. She is a widow with three children; one is a beautician, and the others are attending the local school. Her first child’s business is facing a small problem because her child does not have enough money to buy beauty supplies, so Mrs. Ren K. has decided to ask for a loan to buy the supplies on her child’s behalf.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her child's business

loans.name: Mouv

texts.en:
Mrs. Mouv S. is a resident of Srae Vong village in Takeo province. Her husband, Mr. Lach Phan, is a laborer who earns a small income. She has six children; one is a teacher, and the others are attending the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.  

Mrs. Mouv S. is a farmer who owns a 0.4 hectare field on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her business faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy fertilizers to make her crops more productive. Thus, Mrs. Mouv S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her crops

loans.name: Mork

texts.en:
Mork C. is a hard working woman who resides in the province of Kampong Chhnang, Cambodia.

Here she earns a living by selling vegetables and raising pig as well. She and her husband also cultivate a rice crop during the farming season.

The couple was married years ago and doesn’t have a child, but they plan to give birth next year.

Mork C. seeks capital to purchase piglets to raise as well as to accumulate various vegetables to fulfill the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and vegetables.

loans.name: Lonh

texts.en:
Lonh S., 44, is a low-income woman living in Kampong Chhnang Province, in Cambodia, where she and her husband earn a living as chicken traders. Lonh S. has given birth to three children, who are employed in different occupations.

The couple goes to buy chicken in bulk from citizens who live in the rural area and then they bring them to sell to their customers who are retail sellers in the market.

Lonh S. requests a loan for capital to sustain the growth of her chicken selling business

loans.use: As capital for her chicken selling business.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma G. is a 33 year old entrepreneur from Maricaban, Pasay City. She has two children; the eldest is now in grade school and the youngest still stays home.

Her husband Edilberto, 39, is a welder.

Alma’s sari-sari (general) store is barely two years in operation yet she already earns more than 18000 PHP a month. She also sells charcoal. She religiously attends to her business to better improve it.

In 2001, Alma joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.

She is now on her 20th loan cycle and is applying for a 35000 PHP loan from CCT which she said she will use to expand her store by purchasing more items to sell.

Alma saves most of her profits to be able to acquire their own place to live and do business (they are currently renting their place).

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Capital for business expansion.

loans.name: Pho

texts.en:
Pho P., 27, is a low-income woman who resides in a rural area of Kampong Chhnang province. She now has two kids, who are dependent on her care.

Pho P. sells fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing. She earns $3 per day.

Pho P. is taking out her loan to repair her broken motorcycle that affects her ability to earn income.

loans.use: To repair her motorcycle that affects her ability to earn income.

loans.name: Aun's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Aun K. is the leader of a group of four members who all live in Damnak village in Takeo province. She is 43 years old and the mother of a child who is attending the local school.  Mrs. Aun K. is a Khmer noodle seller and also a pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets and pig food for breeding. She would use the rest of the money from her loan to buy fertilizer to support the plantation of her husband, Mr. Try Phat.

loans.use: to purchse pig-breeding supplies, and fertilizer for her husband

loans.name: Hel

texts.en:
Hel S., 33, was married years ago and her marriage has resulted in seven children who are still young and attend school.

She has been operating a small handicraft business since 2000. S. has a skill of making local basket accessories by hand with bamboo, while her husband has a skill of decorating wood for building.

Hel S. wants to earn more income by operating another line of work.

Because Hel S. doesn't have adequate money, she would like to ask for a loan from Kiva through HKL to be used to order rice in bulk to resell to raise her income.

loans.use: To order rice in bulk to resell.

loans.name: Mrs. Nath Paor Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of fourteen people, is located in Khnar Thum village in Takeo province and each member will use the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Nath P. is the village bank president. She is a fruit seller. Her husband, Mr. Art Sak, is a farmer who owns 2.5-hectare (6.25-acre) piece of land on which he cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, he is also a motorbike taxi driver.

In his plantation, Mr. Art Sak needs some money to buy farming supplies. Thus, Mrs. Nath P. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizers to support the rice field and make the crops more productive.

Mrs. Nath P. is 44 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is a laborer while another three are enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is just 3 years old.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizers to support her rice field

loans.name: Mrs. Sokly Phan Village Bank Group

texts.en: Twelve people who all live in the village of Khnar Thum in Takeo Province make up the group that is requesting this village bank loan. Mrs. Sokly P. is a village bank president who has selected the members, and they all will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sokly P. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land for cultivating rice. She is a 41-year-old widow with a child who is a weaver. Mrs. Sokly P. is requesting a loan to buy more raw materials for her child, while her child's business is going well.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials for her child's weaving business

loans.name: Hun

texts.en: Hun T., 29, is single and makes a living as a seamstress. She lives with her mother, who earns money by weaving basket accessories by hand from bamboo. They live in poor conditions because their house is too old and small for them. Hun T. has applied for a loan for $1,000 to build a new house for them to live in.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda T. lives in the village of Macanhan, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 62 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a store where she sells green bananas. Nilda has been engaged in this business for over 35 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Nilda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and ability to engage in business activities. Nilda is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional income made possible by the loan to improve her family's life. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell

location.town: Macanhan, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen T. lives in the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old, married and has four school-aged children. She makes a living as the owner and operator of an "okay-okay" shop where she sells clothes. Helen has been in this business for more than two years.

Earlier this year, Helen joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living conditions and ability to engage in business. She is applying for her first loan from GDMPC, for 5,000 PHP, to buy additional clothing to sell. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to pay her children's tuition. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional clothing to sell

loans.name: Vitoria

texts.en:
Vitoria R. lives in  the village of San Isidro, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 39 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She makes a living as the owner and operator of a sari-sari (or variety) store where she sells food and products people use daily. Vitoria has been in this business for more than three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Vitoria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is requesting her first loan, for 5,000 PHP, to buy additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
