Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn S. lives in the village of Oro Culai, Balulang Cagayan De Oro City. She is 27 years old, married and has three young children. To make a living, she owns and operates a store where she sells a variety of products used daily by the people in her community. She has been in this business for more than four years, and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Roselyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and ability to engage in business. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, her first, to buy new items to sell to her custoemrs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to improve and expand her store. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy new items to sell to her customers

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Josua

texts.en:
Josua R. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 19 years old. Josua is single. To make a living, Josua operates a transportation business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services to transport passengers in the local community. Josua has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josua joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josua is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Josua from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda B. is 46 years old and resides in Barangay Marobbob Amulung, Cagayan. She has three children: Jovelyn, a sixteen year old senior high school student; Jayson, a 12 year old sixth grade student; and Jocelyn, a six year old first grade student. 

Luzviminda has raised pigs behind her house for more than ten years. To meet her family's needs, moreover, she also helps her husband with farming. In order to improve her pig raising business, she decided to ask for a PHP 3,000 loan from the Kiva lenders. She will use the money to purchase more piglets.

loans.use: purchasing more piglets

loans.name: Everlyn

texts.en:
Everlyn T. is from the village of Mison, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old. Everlyn is married and has 3 infants. Everlyn's main source of income comes from operating a clothing business. Everlyn has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Everlyn joined GDMPC in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Everlyn is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase more ready made clothing for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Everlyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing more ready made clothing for sale

loans.name: Hermenia

texts.en:
Hermenia G. is from the town of Talakag Bukidnon. She is 53 years old. Hermenia is separated from her spouse. To make a living, Hermenia owns and runs a "sari-sari" (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products to the community. Hermenia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Hermenia joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hermenia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Hermenia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve and expand the business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: investing in expanding her business

loans.name: Mylin

texts.en:
Mrs. Mylin T. and her husband Ronnie T. of Barangay Baresbes, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya, want to be successful in order to give their only son a better future. They endure many hardships in their efforts to survive.

Ronnie is a security guard in one of the companies in Solano while Mylin manages a small "sari-sari" (variety) store in their village. She sells different grocery items and snacks. She is able to earn a net income of PHP 5,000 a month, which they use to meet their daily needs; any money left over is saved to provide for the future of their son. Mylin wants to acquire more additional items to sell but her capital is not enough; consequently, she wants to borrow PHP 9,000 from the Kiva lenders to be used in acquiring the said additional items. She believes that through her patience and sacrifices, she can improve her small business.

loans.use: purchasing new products for her "sari-sari" (variety) store

loans.name: Linalyn

texts.en:
Linalyn M. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Linalyn is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Linalyn owns and operates a bakery. The main source of income for the business comes from selling baked bread to the community. Linalyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month.

In 2009, Linalyn joined GDMPC in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Linalyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional equipment. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Linalyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve and expand her business.
 
About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: purchasing additional equipment

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en: Teodora G. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 38 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children. Teodora owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Teodora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn M. is from the village of Macanhan, Cagayuan De Oro City. She is 33 years old. Evelyn is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling green bananas in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 7 years.

In 2009, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a loan which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Macanhan, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Fredelina

texts.en:
Fredelina B. is known as” Freding”. She is now 50 years old and has three children. She is married to Mr. Daniel B. and they live happily together in the village of Baresbes, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. As parents, they are concerned with the future of their children so they are sending them to school. Two of their children already finished a vocational course and are presently working in a department Store. 

Her husband is a farmer and a caretaker in the Municipality of Quezon while Fredilina manages a sari-sari store in their village to earn additional income. She aims to improve her sari-sari store but she does not have enough money. She wants a loan of Php7,000 to increase her capital and improve her small business.

loans.use: addtional capital and the improvement of her sari-sari store

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna E. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a business venture in the arts sector rating a beautician.While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing manicures and pedicures in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 2 years. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for manicure and pedicure

loans.name: Cerelina

texts.en:
“At the back of hardships and difficulties, there is a valley of Success”, that's an inspiring quotation shared by Cerelina G., a responsible house wife of Eduardo G.. They live in a village of Brgy. Baresbes, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. They have four children; three of them are now in elementary level while the youngest is not yet studying. Being parents, they want their children to finish their studies so that they will be employ in the good job someday.
	In this regard, they help each other to cultivate their farm lots by planting rice and some vegetables twice in a year. Since they are financially shortened,Cerelina put-up a small general store in front of their house to earn additional income. Since she has inadequate capital, she wants to borrow from KIVA lenders an amount of P 5,000.00 to be able to increase her capital in improving her small store. She is thankful if the lenders will grant her request because it is a great opportunity to improve her small business and she hopes that she can able to increase her income and support the schooling of their children.

loans.use: additional capital to improve her general store

loans.name: Peou

texts.en: S., 29, is a low-income worker living in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a good and determined single mother who tries to feed her mother and child, even though she has recently been divorced from her husband. She has a lovely child who lives in the family home. S. sells fresh fish in the local market to earn a living. Every day in the late morning, S. goes to a place that is full of fisherman to buy fish in bulk. Then she hurries to bring the fish to the market, which she sells for retail. In the past, S. always paid a lot of money for a taxi to pick up fish to the market. She right now hopes to own a vehicle and is applying for a loan, which she will use to buy an old motorbike.

loans.use: To buy an old motorbike

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina A. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Lina is 25 years old and is married with a husband that is a business man. She has 3 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to settle down in.

loans.use: stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Vivianita

texts.en:
Vivianita P. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Vivianita owns and operates a business making and selling "saging ginanghang" snacks (banana cue: plantain, fried in boiling oil and held on a skewer) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Vivianita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more bananas for making snacks. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas for making snacks

loans.name: Agatuna

texts.en: Agatuna D. is from the village of Katipunan, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 51 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Agatuna owns and operates a business planting and harvesting cassava for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Agatuna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Agatuna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Rotsie

texts.en:
Rotsie C. lives in the village of Balulang, Cagayan De Oro City. Rotsie is 25 years old, married, and has 2 small children. Rotsie owns & operates a business selling vegetables among other things which she has been doing for the past three years. She earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rotsie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rotsie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Rotsie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Business Expansion

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
One of Cherry's guiding beliefs is that only through sacrifice can one find success in life. Cherry is a industrious wife and mother. She is married and she and her husband Mario are blessed with three children, two of whom are married and have families of their own. Jacky, their 23 year old daughter and a high school graduate, is still single.

Cherry sells cosmetics in the village and also raises hogs and owns a fish pond. She is thankful because her business is improving but she would like it to grow further to help her youngest child. She is asking for a loan of PHP 7,000 to purchase cosmetics, products to increase the productivity of her fish pond, and food for her hogs. Cherry hopes that her businesses will be profitable.

loans.use: Merchandise for her business, food for her hogs, products for her fish pond

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Luy

texts.en: Luy S. is 42 years old and lives in the province of Kompong Tom, Cambodia.  She and her husband own a plot of land next to their house and grow  rice and vegetables. Luy S. also braids traditional mats for sale. She is a devoted mother to three children, who are no longer in school. Two of them are employed: one is a garment worker and one works in construction. Luy S. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and seeds for growing potatoes.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for growing potatoes

loans.name: Honeylyn

texts.en:
Honeylyn operates a motorcycle transport business and sells cosmetic products in the village of Rizal, Santiago City. She is 31 years of age and married. She is blessed with four children: Lucky Renbel, 11 years old, Jeric, 9 years old, Dexter, 7 years old, and Lyka May, 2 years old.

The couple works hard to earn enough money to meet their children's need. Honeylyn helps her husband by earning additional income selling cosmetic products. Honeylyn is thankful for her business's improvement. Her husband is involved in the motorcycle transport business and also cultivates rice to improve their quality of life. Honeylyn would like to borrow working capital to improve their businesses. She is requesting Php 8,000 for the maintenance of her motorcycle which is an important element in supporting the day-to-day needs of her family.

loans.use: Motorcycle maintenance

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Cristoto

texts.en:
Cristoto S. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan De Oro City. Cristoto is 43 years old, married, and has 4 school-aged children. Cristoto buys and sells gold dust from the local mines. Cristoto has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Cristoto joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristoto has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Cristoto is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase more gold dust to expand his business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Cristoto from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support education of children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase gold dust to expand his business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en: Sacrifice and patience are needed in order to achieve success in life, says Rolando E.. He buys scrap materials within the village of Rizal Santiago and is also engaged in a rice-farming business. Rolando is married to Criselda and they are blessed with three children: Rowena - 11 years old; Remar - ten years old, and Lea - nine years old.  Rolando is requesting a loan of  Php6,000 to buy more scrap in order to generate a bigger income for his family's needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for business growth

loans.name: Vergie

texts.en:
Vergie S., from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental, is 42 years old, married and has four grown children. To make a living, Vergie owns and operates a business whose income comes primarily from buying and selling shells in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Vergie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional equipment for buying shells for sale, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support extended members of the family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional equipment for buying shells to sell

loans.name: Melik

texts.en:
Melik H. is 60 and lives in Kaghnut village in the Kapan area. He is married and has three sons. His wife works at a chemist's shop (pharmacy) as a pharmaceutist. All of Melik’s sons are employees and one of them lives in a separate house with his family.

Melik works as a brigade-leader in an organization where he repairs factory equipment. At the same time, he has land where he grows grain. During sowing and harvest time, working hours last about twelve hours a day. Also, because he hasn’t got his own agricultural equipment, he has to wait till the other farmers’ equipment is free in order to rent it.

So, Melik needs a 1,100,000 AMD loan to buy a plough and separator to cut down his expenses and to use his time more rationally.

loans.use: To buy a plough and separator for his farm

loans.name: Haliba

texts.en:
Haliba S., currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol, is requesting a loan to purchase more materials for the business. Haliba is 25 years old and married to a policeman. They have two children, both attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for the business

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a young Palestinian man living in Bethlehem. He is married with six children.

Ahmad owns a barber shop in the old city of Bethlehem. He started this business when he was still 18 years old as he likes hairstyles. He took several training sessions to be professional. He has another employee in the shop who helps him, as barber shops in Palestine work for long hours, starting in the morning and running till late in the evening. They have only Monday as their day off (a requirment of the Barber Association).

Ahamad requested from FATEN a 3,000 USD loan to renovate his shop and make new decor to attract more customers. He will also use the loan to buy new products for hair and skin treatment.

Ahmad appears in the picture at the entrance to his shop.

loans.use: To renovate his shop and to buy new products

loans.name: Chean

texts.en: Chean R., 30, lives in the province of Kompong Tom, Cambodia and has been a vegetable trader for more than a year.  She also buys various vegetables in bulk from rural farmers and then retails them in the market for income. Chean R. is married to Sun Som, who decorates wooden  furniture. This couple has two school-aged children. Chean R. is requesting a loan to purchase a trailer to connect to an existing motorbike which her husband will use to transport furniture to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to connect to an existing motorbike to transport furniture

loans.name: Nueva

texts.en:
Mrs. Nueva P. is married, 41 years old, and has five school-aged children. Her husband is a fisherman and they currently live at Lutao, Panaon, Misamis Occidental.

Nueva joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. 

Nueva is requesting a loan of 14,900 PHP as additional capital for her business. This will be her 9th loan from PMPC. Her husband’s income s not enough for their daily needs, especially if the weather is not good, so she is planning to use the loan to purchase additional items like manicure set, pedicure set, towels, nail polish, etc.

Nueva plans to expand her manicure/pedicure service into a parlor and wishes to see their family succeed in their chosen field of business.

loans.use: To purchase items for her manicure and pedicure business

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa L. is a widow, 71 years old, and has five adult children. The family currently lives at Lutao, Panaon, Misamis Occidental.

In 2004, Narcisa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.

Narcisa is requesting a loan of 9,500 PHP as additional capital for her sari-sari (variety) store. This will be her 10th loan from PMPC. Since she has no husband anymore to help her in obtaining income, Narcisa works hard to support her family needs. She is planning to use the loan amount to purchase additional items for her sari-sari store.

loans.use: To purchase additional items for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Ladu

texts.en:
Ladu N. is in the business of selling bread and cakes in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase other items such as tomatoes, fresh fish, onions, etc., to sell. Ladu is 23 years old and married to a soldier. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase items such as tomatoes, fresh fish, onions, etc., to sell

loans.name: Felymar

texts.en:
Felymar M. is a 53 year old businesswoman in their village. She is married to Dante, 59, who is presently working in the Department of Agriculture in their village. The couple has three diligent children: Harden, 38, a high school graduate; Harold, 22, a college graduate working in Manila as a machine operator; and Harlyn, 17, a first-year college student taking up Information Technology. They live at Barangay Estefania Amulung, Cagayan. Felymar wants a good future for her children. By engaging in business, she hopes to support the growing needs of her children. 

Felymar started managing her general store when she got married. She wanted to earn income for her family, most especially for her children. Felymar is requesting a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP10,000. She will use the loan as additional capital to continuously improve and expand her retailing business. With the help of the loan, she will be able to purchase more items to sell.

loans.use: Additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly F. is from the village of Pagatpat, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 48 years old. Beverly is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Beverly operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Beverly has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos a month for these activities.

In 2008, Beverly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beverly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Beverly is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand the number of products she offers. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Beverly from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the number of products offered

location.town: Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda G. is a good mother who is committed to improve the living conditions of her family through hard work, perseverance and love. This is the life path that she has chosen for herself and her family. Erlinda is a 49 year old married woman who lives in the village of Brgy. Gargato, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. Her husband is a tricycle driver and also operates their motorized fishing boat - locally known as a pumpboat. They have eight children who are between 15 to 35 years old with the younger ones still attending school. Having been blessed with eight children, they knew they had to work hard to provide for their large family, especially in terms of preparing them to be independent and have their own livelihoods when they are grown. 

What should have been a difficult situation became an opportunity for Erlinda to help her husband support their family, and with the help of NWTF Project Dungganon, she was able to get enough capital to earn a respectable living for their family. Years ago, Erlinda was actually starting to worry how they could support and educate eight kids, but with determination, she started selling her husband's catch to her neighbors, going as far as the nearby villages just so she could sell the fish her husband caught each day. Then, as she developed good relationships with her customers, she also sold dried fish to them.

Because she wanted to expand her business, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 to access additional capital without pawning any of their meager properties. With the help of her loans, she was able to buy additional materials for her fishing business and was able to buy more for her fish vending business. Her business continued to improve and now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000, which is quite enough to support their needs with some left over for savings.

In her last loan she borrowed Php 19,500 which she used to add to her working capital and also paid for maintenance work on their fishing boat. The loan was paid in weekly installments and was fully paid within her loan term without any delays. Now she is borrowing her tenth cycle loan for the same amount of Php 19,500, which she will use as additional working capital for her businesses. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her fishing business

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem K.,48, is a rattan cupboard maker and widowed mother caring for six children. Two of her children are employed: A son is a carpenter and is also hired by villagers to help with plowing their farms; and a daughter is a worker who sews clothes. Since 2007, Sem K. has owned a small rattan cupboard sales point. Sem K. requested a loan to purchase a trailer and old motor, which she will use to transport her rattan to sell door-to-door. Sem K. and her son are pictured at their house.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer and old motor

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 46 years old, married, and is the mother of four children. Her husband is retired and his pension is $250.

She has experience of twenty years in this business and nine years ago she established her own shop. She has received three loans including this one, and has made all the repayments in a timely manner. As a result of these loans she raised her income and became capable of getting more customers.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is from the village of Tumpagon, a barangay of Cagayan De Oro City on Mindanao Island. She is 47 years old, married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth sells firewood to the local community. She has been in business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her fourth, from HSPFI of 11000 PHP (she successfully repaid her third loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI). Elizabeth will use this loan to purchase additional firewood to sell. She plans to use all additional revenue to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional firewood to sell.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Jeneffer

texts.en:
Jeneffer C. is from the village of Bayabay within Barangay Panalsalan in Misamis Occidental Province, Mindanao. She is 25 years old, married and has one infant. Jeneffer sells fish to the local community. She has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jeneffer joined GDMPC to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC which she will use to purchase more fish to sell. She plans to use any additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Melodina

texts.en:
Melodina D. is from the village of Tumpagon, a barangay in Cagayan De Oro City on Mindanao. She is 33 years old, married and has five school-aged children. Melodina sells specialty food products from her food stall to the local community. Melodina has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Melodina joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her fourth, of 11000 PHP from HSPFI which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. Melodina successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to buy ingredients for the food she sells. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to pay for her children’s education.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is a 60-year-old widow who is bringing up her nephew and taking care of him because his father passed away. She receives a pension for the loss of her family member.

She depends on sewing and tailoring clothes for the neighbors. This income is used to earn her living and support the child as well.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and fabric

loans.name: Jafari

texts.en: Jafari S. is a Tanzanianan entrepreneur and a married man. He runs a hardware shop at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam.  He sells various business goods including cement. He purchases the materials from the wholesale hardware shops and sells at retail. He has been in the business for the past 10 years and he managed to buy a car with his business income. His business plan is to run a wholesale shop but capital is the most limiting factor. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to boost his business.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Noly

texts.en:
Noly D. is a young and strong 60-year-old who loves running her business and is happy to be earning a daily income from her business operations. She lives in the village of Brgy. 111, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She is married to a motorcycle driver and they have three children who are between 21 and 30 years old. Noly has always dreamed of a more comfortable life for herself and her family.

She had to do something to help her husband earn a living because his income from driving a motorcycle, shuttling passengers, was just not sufficient to sustain their family. So Noly started her own eatery, offering different kinds of food to her regular customers. In spite of the small income she earned from this business, she persisted because it helped their food needs.

To improve her business and be able to earn a bigger income, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon 2001. With the additional capital from her loans, she was soon able to expand her business to include a general store. She has been in business for over 25 years already, but it is only now with the help of NWTF-Project Dungganon that she is finally achieving some success in her business. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 9,000 from her business operations, allowing her to set aside some savings for their future.

In her previous loan, she borrowed Php 17,000 and used it as working capital for her eatery and to buy more stock for her general store. Even at her age, she maintains her good credit performance by paying her loan in full and on time without any delays. Now she is borrowing for her 16th cycle loan, the same amount of Php 17,000 to be used to buy motorcycle spare parts to repair her husband's source of his livelihood and also as additional capital for her general store and eatery.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for her husband's motorcycle and as additional capital for her eatery and general store

loans.name: Lule

texts.en:
M. is a 55-year-old married mother with six children aged between 14 and 23 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house, where she is staying with seven people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from Kawala. She works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala. 

M. works seven days a week. She receives an average of 30 customers a day and sells to all categories of people on a retail basis. She owns a canteen selling candles and water. Her major business challenges include ever increasing prices of candle wax and the rainy season, which hinders her customers to reach out to her because she works from an open place.  

Her monthly expenses include rent for her business premises, feeding the family and medication. She has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for four years, servicing her ninth loan. M. joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with it. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of candle wax and to pay her water bill. She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to start distributing samosas, chapatti and pancakes to different nearby schools.

loans.use: To buy more candle wax and to pay water bills for water distribution

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen O. is a 46-year-old married woman who currently resides in the territory of Kompong Tom, a province of Cambodia. She is a local merchant who has been in business for more than three years.

Pen O. is blessed with four children; three are married and have started new homes and the other one is single. All of her children are employed in different jobs. Her husband is a carpenter who decorates wood to be used for furniture. Pen O. hopes to earn more income by using her loan to purchase a cultivating machine to provide a plowing service for farmers.

loans.use: To purchase a cultivating machine to provide a plowing service for farmers

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie is a 31 year-old single mother of two children aged 9 and 16 years. Both her children go to school. She rents and resides in a one room house where she lives with three people. Marjorie doesn’t take care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but not piped water and gets three meals a day.

She incurs transportation costs to buy clothing materials and food stuffs from the Nakawa market. She works in a semi-urban area that is on the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a stall in Kyebando and sells snacks in the market. Marjorie sells all types of snacks ranging from samosas, mandazi chapatti, pancakes, and kebabs. Marjorie works seven days a week and receives an average of 35 customers a day.

Her major business challenges include the increasing prices of cooking oil, wheat flour, and baking powder and the rainy season which disturbs her work because she works in an open area. Her monthly expenses include rent for her residence, monthly market dues, food for her family, and medication.

Aside from her snack business, she also operates a pre-primary school near her home. She has been in this business for over two years and with MCDT for five years. She is servicing her tenth loan with the same group members. Marjorie joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of the ability to work in a group. She wants to use this loan to buy more cooking oil, wheat flour, and baking powder. She is hoping to see her business grow bigger to start supplying different shops and schools.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil, wheat flour, and baking powder

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 44 years old and is the father of two children. He has sixteen years experience in carpentry and established this shop six years ago. He works by customer request and works as a contractor.

The purpose behind this loan is to purchase tools and wood to raise his income as well as to expand his shop.

loans.use: To purchasing wood and a machine to cut wood

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni R. is currently in the business of selling dried fish in the market and is requesting a loan to stock other items like onions, tomatoes, etc., for sale.

Poni is 29 years-old and married. Her husband is a soldier. She has 2 children who go to school. With the extra income from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock additional items like onions, tomatoes, etc., for sale

loans.name: Felista

texts.en: Felista L. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and businesswoman. She is married with three school-age children. She runs a café at Tandika District in Dar es Salaam. The business has enabled her to buy a plot of land for house construction, to pay the children school fees and to have capital for the business. She is comfortable with her business but her future plans are to expand the business by modifying the existing business and opening another business. She has been in the business for four years. She needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more business goods

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 45-year-old married mother of nine children between the ages of 12 and 28. Five of her children go to school. She owns a three-room house where she lives with ten people. Joyce takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transportation costs to and from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala city. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Joyce works six days a week, receiving an average of four customers a day. She works with all categories of people.

Joyce owns a ladies' beauty salon in Mengo Kisenyi. Her major business challenges include the ever-increasing prices of hair conditioners and hair extensions as well as the rainy season, which hinders her customers coming to her because she works from a muddy place. Her monthly expenses include rent for her business premises, feeding the family and medication. She has been in this business for twenty years and with MCDT for four years, now servicing her 8th loan.

Joyce joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with the people. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of hair conditioners and extensions. She is hoping to see her business grow bigger and would like to start a bridal salon.

loans.use: To buy more hair condtioners and extensions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase computers and printers

loans.name: Jesusa

texts.en:
Jesusa G. is 49 years old and a resident of Barangay Estefania, Amulung, Cagayan. She is married to Romeo G. who is 50 years old and who is a local laborer in their village. They are blessed with eight grown up children The first four of her children are high school graduates and already married, while the others are still studying. Jesusa hopes that through her business and her husband’s source of income, they will be able to provide all the needs of their children, especially when it comes to their education.

Jesusa is a hog raiser. She wants her hogs to grow healthy so she can sell them at higher prices. Another source of income Jesusa manages is her vending business. She sells vegetables in their village and generates a profit of $38 a month. This is a good business for her because it is where her family gets their daily expenses. She always hopes to further expand her business to provide sufficient support for her family. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP. This amount will assist her in providing the hogs with enough feed for their growth and also be used for her vegetable vending business.

loans.use: additional capital for her businesses

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Genelyn

texts.en:
Genelyn T. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Genelyn owns and operates a business buying and selling fish, shellfish and crabs in the local community. Genelyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $75 a month from these activities.

Genelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Genelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This this will be her 1st loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Mr. Sourn Y., 43, owns a vehicle which he uses to provide a taxi service for income. He operates his service along the streets in the province, and he also picks up the passers-by who need to go to market. His wife stays at home, selling sugar cane juice and sweets for kids to earn a living (she is shown in the photo).

This couple has two teenage children; one of them provides a horse-cart service, and the other one attends school. Recently, Sourn Y.’s financial income is declining because his old vehicle often has problems. Therefore, he needs a loan so he can trade it in for a better one.

loans.use: To exchange his broken taxi

loans.name: Iyad

texts.en:
Iyad, age 33, is a responsible father of six children who has always watched over his family’s financial security. He accomplishes this by raising and selling sheep. He purchases sheep, feeds and cares for them, and then resells them at higher prices.

He applied for a loan of $2000 to purchase more sheep. You could become an important part of his family's life. He deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

loans.use: to purchase more sheep

loans.name: Grolia

texts.en: Grolia F. M. is a business entrepreneur and a married woman. She has four school-age children. Two are in primary and the rest in secondary school. She runs a poultry farm. She keeps both broilers and layers at her farm. She collects twenty trays of eggs from the poultry cages per day and sells at wholesale and retail to customers. She has been in the business for three years and the business income enables her to meet the family's daily demands and expand the business. She needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to construct more poultry cages and buy more chicks.

loans.use: To buy more chicks and build more cages

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en:
Ma. Luz S. lives in the village of Prk Malipayon, Brgy Sagasa, Bago City, Negros Occidental. She is 48 years old and is married to Jerry S., who works as a farmer. She has 8 children; one already has his own family, and the rest are still attending school. As a mother, she would like to secure the future of her children by making sure that they have very good jobs and enough earnings to support the needs of their own families when they decide to settle down. 

Ma. Luz got married at only 19 years old because she wanted to be free of her parents' strictness. When she had her own family, she encountered a lot of hardships and problems on how to cope with their daily living. She knew that her husband's income as a farmer was not enough for them. When their first baby was born, Ma. Luz tried other ways to earn other income like putting up a small general store at the front of her house while raising ducks in her backyard. In spite of the additional business, they still encountered problems; still, they persevered.   

In 2001 Ma. Luz was able to join NWTF-Project Dungganon, which gave her additional capital for their business. With the loan, she was able to buy additional ducks to raise so that she could then sell the eggs to their neighbors. As loans continued, she learned how to handle her money. She was also able to invest in pig fattening, acquire a farmland and buy a water buffalo for their farm. Twenty six years later, Ma.Luz is more knowledgeable on how to manage her businesses. She now earns PHP 10,000 per month. Most of the profit is put in a savings account to support the education of their children and to help with the family expenses.

For her previous loan, Ma. Luz borrowed PHP 13,000. Said loan was paid in full and on time. Now, while on her 18th cycle, she is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000. She will use the money to buy additional ducks to raise and egg trays for the delivery of eggs. The resulting income will be used to improve her family's living conditions, pay for her children's education and renovate her house.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: purchasing additional ducks to raise

loans.name: Germina

texts.en:
Germina is a 78 year old widowed mother of 7 children aged between 46 and 58 years.  None of her children goes to school. She owns and resides in a four-roomed house, where she is staying with ten people. Germina takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.  Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and buying medication.  

Germina works seven days a week.  She owns a pub in Mengo Kisenyi, and incurs transportation costs to and from Owino, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city. She receives an average of 10 customers a day and works to sell to all categories of people. Her major business challenges include the ever-increasing price of beer and the rainy season, which hinders her customers from reaching her because she works in a muddy place.  She has been in this business for thirty years and with MCDT – who are servicing her tenth loan – for five.  Germina joined MCDT because it was near her home and was easy to work with. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer . She hopes to see her business grow bigger so she can start dealing exclusively in wholesale.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita S. is from the village of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old, married, and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a clothing business. The primary source of income for the business comes from sewing and repairing clothes in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Teresita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC, and is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional clothes for her business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Teresita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small business owners.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional clothes for her business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This client is 42 years old, is married and has two kids. He has worked in this shop for six years. He has good experience in computer networking because he worked previously in Information Technology in a company related to the networks.

He needs this loan to purchase new computers and to hire a waiter to serve his clients. This will increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase new computers for his Internet café

loans.name: Jovitha

texts.en: Jovitha Samson is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and married woman. She has three school-age children. She runs a café at Yombo Makangarawe in Dar es Salaam. The business goods are purchased from the city markets at Tandika and Kariakoo and from the wholesale shops. She managed to build a house and meet her family's daily demands from her business income. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,200,000 to expand the business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Dia'a

texts.en:
Dia'a is a police officer in the Palestinian National Authority and has three children.

Diaa's wife is studying in the university and Dia'a has requested a 2,000 USD loan from FATEN to pay his wife university tuition.

Dia'a work is the only source of income for the family and is not enough to cover daily expenses. He hopes that after his wife finishes her degree she will help him by getting a job and consequently the family will have a better income to meet its daily expenses.

Dia'a appears in the photo at the FATEN branch office.

loans.use: To pay for his wife's university tuition

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 25 years old and the father of two children. He has operated this shop for five years.

This is the third loan that he has received from Al-Thiqa to develop his shop and the loans have enabled him to raise his income and gain lots of customers. He made all his repayments in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phones

loans.name: Mean

texts.en: Mean N. was born in 1967 and is a good father to four children. One of them is married, and the other three are single; all are living together in the family home. To help support the family, three of the children are working in a variety of occupations. Mean N. is a motorbike taxi driver who earns around $4 a day for his services. His wife appears in the picture. She owns a store where she sells different kinds of produce items, including vegetables, meats, and some other groceries. Mean N. is requesting a loan to help increase his savings in order to build a new house for his married child to live in.

loans.use: to build a new house for his married child to live in

loans.name: Ma. Lourdes

texts.en:
Ma. Lourdes G. lives in the village of Brgy San Jose, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She is 35 years old, married, and has 2 children aged nine and fourteen years old who are presently attending school. She works hard because she wants to give her children all they need, including good food, an education and a good family to support them when they grow up.  She also wants to help her husband earn additional income for their family.

In the past, she was a plain housewife whose main day-to-day activity was to take good care of her children and husband. She would wait for her husband to bring home his salary and then budget it for the week.  However, she noticed that the budget was never enough for the whole week. She thought of trying to start a business so she could earn money and help her husband, which is why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon.   Having some capital to invest in business, Ma. Lourdes decided to try her luck with a ready-to-wear and used clothing business. She goes to different places to sell her goods. She wakes up early to go to market and sell her wares so that she can earn more income. From her business, she is able to earn PHP 10,000 every month, which is a big help to her family, especially for the education of her two children.

Ma. Lourdes’ previous loan of PHP 19,500 was used to buy additional clothes, both ready-to-wear and used. Because the funds went toward her business, she was able to maintain a good credit rating by paying her previous loan on time and in full, without any delay. Now, for her 11th cycle loan, she is borrowing the same amount of PHP 19,500, which she will use for her business, to save for her children’s education, and for household expenses.

In the picture, Ma. Lourdes is involved in her business during market day.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned its respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet M. manages a general store. She is 23 years old and married to Jake M., a tricycle driver in their village. The couple is blessed with two loving children; Mary-Elaiza, age four and Keanna Mae age two.  The couple works hard to help their children achieve a high level of education. They are thankful because they are able to support their children.

Janet would like to expand her store and buy more groceries to sell and would like to ask for additional capital from KIVA lenders in the amount of Php5,000.  She would be glad if this amount is loaned.

loans.use: Expand grocery store business.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret P. selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan so she can buy and stock more bags of charcoal for sell.  Margret is 29 years old and is married.  Her husband is a soldier. They have five children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to build a house for her family.
-----------------------------
 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal for sell.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is 39 years old and married to William. Her husband helps her buy and sell junk materials. They are blessed with six children.  She buys scrap materials in her village and sells those materials in big junk shops. She also sells cosmetics products. 

Yolanda would like to borrow PHP6,000 to purchase more products for her customers and to buy more scrap.  The additional capital will help her growth her business.  She would be thankful if KIVA lenders loan her the money.

loans.use: Capital for business development.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is a 44 year widowed mother of with five children.  They are ages 14 to 25.  Three go to school.  She rents a two room house where she stays with six people. Regina takes care of additional family members. They have access to electricity but no piped water.  They eat two meals a day.   

She spend money to get to and from work, near the outskirts of Kampala.  She serves an average of 20 customers a day, seven days a week and sells second-hand clothes, door to door.  Her major challenges include buying second hand clothes, because prices are rising and the rainy season which slows sales.  

Her monthly expenses include feeding the family, medication and rent.  She's been in this business for twenty years and with MCDT for five years.  She is servicing her tenth loan.  Regina joined MCDT because it was near her home and easy to work with.  She wants to use this loan to buy bales of second hand clothes. She hopes to sell wholesale only and to own a permanent business premise.

loans.use: Buy bales of second hand clothes.

loans.name: Lelia

texts.en:
Lelia D., 62, is a widow from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan De Oro City. She has one adult-aged child. For over five years, Lelia has owns and operates a business that make and sells specialty food products in her local community. Lelia earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Lelia joined HSPFI to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Lelia is requesting the same amount now to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fourth from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 
-------------------------------------------------
About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Simeon

texts.en: Simeon, a resident of Ughelli, Delta State, Nigeria, is 38 years old and married with three children. His youngest child is just two weeks old and he is very happy about his new baby.  Simeon sells electrical materials at retail prices to his customers and one day hopes to own a big electrical shop.  He is requesting a loan of 65,000 NGN to purchase more electrical materials to sell. Simeon says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical materials to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This client was born in 1985 and is single. Since childhood he worked with his father and learnt a lot from him. Four years ago he established this shop for himself and carried on his work.

This is the second loan that he will receive from Al-Thiqa. The loan will increase his business and he will gain a good profit.

loans.use: To purchase iron and a welding machine

loans.name: Jasmin

texts.en:
Jasmin A. lives in Brgy 3, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She is 46 years old and married. She has five children, two of whom have already graduated from college as nurses. She is working hard for the future of her three remaining children whom they continue to send to school. Jasmin started her business by baking foods like pastries and cakes. It is a trade she learned years ago and discovered that she has the knack for. She started selling these foods to her community and other neighboring villages. She also accepted orders for her baked goods. But in the year 2001, she needed additional capital to buy ingredients for her business so that she could accommodate all the orders. Luckily, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to address her need of additional capital. She was able to buy ingredients so she could meet all her deadlines for the orders.

As her loan continued, she also started a cross-stitch business. With the knowledge she acquired on how to do cross-stitch, she was able to make beautiful, neat and clean products. The new business has contributed to her income. For the two businesses, she is able to earn about $220 a month. She saves most of her income to support the education of her children and the rest is used to support the needs of her family. A previous loan of 27,000 PHP was used as additional working capital for her baked products and cross-stitch businesses. Because of her success, she was able to maintain her good credit performance with NWTF-Project Dungganon. She was able to pay off the loan in full and on time. Now on her 16th cycle loan, with the same amount of 27,000 PHP, Jasmin will buy additional materials for her cross-stitch and baked goods businesses. Whatever income she gets will be used for the education of her children. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy materials for her cross-stitch & baking businesses

loans.name: Honey Lou

texts.en:
Honey Lou H. is from the village of Balanlinao, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 19 years old and married. To make a living, Honey Lou owns and operates a business making and selling food. She sells bread, cakes and cookies to the local community. Honey Lou has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately $50 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Honey Lou joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Honey Lou is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her 1st loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Hatibu

texts.en: Hatibu A. L. is a married Tanzanian small-business man with two children. He runs a business selling music CDs to customers. He purchases the business goods from wholesale suppliers and sells to retail customers. He has been in the business for five years. The income from the business is used to meet his family's daily demands and for business capitalization. His business plan is to open a wholesale shop. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000 to top up the business.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata Traoré est âgée de 51 ans, veuve et mère de 3 enfants, elle vit  avec  ses  enfants dans le quartier Hamdallaye  de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).  
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, Madame  Fatoumata Traoré s’est très vite intéressée au commerce d’articles divers et à la transformation des noix de néré en sounbala. Elle exerce cette activité de transformation depuis plus de 30 ans. Elle est très appréciée et jouit d’une grande notoriété à Koutiala et environs.  
Le sounbala est un produit de première nécessité pour la préparation de certaines sauces en Afrique de l’ouest, ce qui montre toute l’importance  et l’avantage de cette activité qui procure assez de revenus à ces pratiquants.
