Pour remédier aux petites ruptures qu’elle subit et qui la fait perdre de la clientèle, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle  il y a 5 ans.  
Après  8 prêts  solidaires  (prêt du groupe) tous correctement  payés,   elle est à son  6ème  prêt  individuel  et tous les précédents ont été bien payés.  
Elle compte acheter, 10 sacs de noix de néré. Elle  s’approvisionne au grand marché de Koutiala et effectue sa vente  à Bamako (capitale Mali)  à une clientèle essentiellement composée  de femmes, au comptant ou à crédit. 
Avec le renforcement de son fonds de commerce, elle espère sur un bénéfice moyen de 125.000FCFA  par mois  qu’elle envisage  utiliser  pour payer les  intérêts du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso, participer aux dépenses familiales et s’entretenir elle même ainsi que ses enfants. 
Madame  Fatoumata ambitionne  devenir grossiste de condiments  alimentaires à Bamako.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatoumata Traoré, aged 51, is a widow and the mother of three children.  She lives with her children in the Hamdallaye district of Koutiala (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Not having had the chance to go to school, she soon got interested in the commerce of a variety of goods and in the processing of néré nuts into sounbala.  Fatoumata has been in this processing business for over thirty years.  She is much appreciated and enjoys great distinction in Koutiala and the vicinity.  Sounbala is essential for making certain sauces in West Africa, and this speaks to the importance and the advantages of this business, which brings in a fair amount of revenue to those in it. To remedy the sundry shortages which she suffers and which cause her to lose customers, Fatoumata decided five years ago to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy her customers properly.  After eight solidarity loans (group loans), all properly repaid, she is now on her sixth individual loan.  These previous loans have all been repaid.  She intends to buy 10 sacks of néré nuts.  Supplies are gotten at the big market of Koutiala.  Sales are made in cash or on credit to customers composed essentially of woman in Bamako (capital of Mali).  With the boost to her working capital, Fatoumata is hoping for an average profit of 125,000 francs CFA per month that she envisions using to cover the Soro Yiriwaso loan interest, to assist with family expenses, and to support herself, as well as her children.  Her ambition is to become a wholesale merchant of condiments in Bamako.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Néré nuts

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Despite the hardships and difficulties of life, Marites D. and her husband want to send their eight children to school so that they will find a good job someday. They sacrifice their time and endure hardships for the sake of their children. The family lives in the village of Baresbes, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya.

As a way of making income, Marites' husband cultivates their farm lot by planting rice and vegetables, and sometimes he also works as a carpenter. Marites sells snacks and vegetables in their village to help her husband gain income. She wants to sell more snacks and vegetables, but she doesn't have enough capital. Therefore, she wants to borrow 7,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to be used in improving her small business. She hopes that through her patience and sacrifices, and with this financial assistance, she can make her business grow

loans.use: additional capital for her food production business

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en:
Ngozi sells groceries and has been in the business for two years. She has been selling items like tomatoes, bread and milk, but due to the demand for rice and beans, she hopes for a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase rice and beans, along with other groceries, in bulk at a discount. This, she said, will enable her to satisfy her customers' needs and increase her capital and profit.

Ngozi is 31 years old and married, and she has three children. She is a hard-working woman, and she works long hours to make more profit in order to meet the basic needs of her family. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase rice, beans and more groceries in bulk

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa C. is from the village of Libertad, Misamis Oriental. She is 41 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Josefa owns and operates a business providing transport services to local community members using a motorcycle vehicle with her husband as the driver. Josefa has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately $170 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Josefa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Josefa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide this service. Josefa is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. Josefa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 53-year-old widow with six children. She is a focused, hard worker. She is determined to excel in her business and family life. She sells used shoes and bags at retail prices to her customers. The demand for her used shoes and bags is high because there are people in her community who cannot afford new shoes and bags. 

She hopes for 60,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more used shoes and bags to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Aluwesa

texts.en:
Aluwesa J. is currently in the business of selling groundnut phaste (groundnuts crushed into liquid) and charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. Aluwesa is 38 years old and married to a soldier. She has nine children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family settlement.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Bihanga Ii Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
K. Scorastica is a very determined and hardworking lady. She is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is 32 years old and married with 5 children, all of whom are in school. K. works with her husband to make sure that their school fees are cleared. 

K. has been a farmer in the Bihanga trading centre for 12 years now. So far she has been able to make some reasonable profits that have enabled her to increase on her farm size. Her success stems from the fact that she uses manure and fertilizer to ensure that she is selling high quality products. K.'s goal, ultimately, is to have a very large farm that will allow for increased output. 

K. works very hard to give her children a good education. Consequently, she would like to borrow money, with which she will buy more farm inputs.

loans.use: purchasing farm inputs

loans.name: Savuth

texts.en: Mr. Savuth N. lives in the village of Srae Srang in Takeo Province. To earn a living, he is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare piece of land for cultivating rice. On his plantation, he faces the obstacle of infertile soil, which has a bad effect on his crops. Thus, he has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers for the field in order to make his crops more productive. His wife, Mrs. Nuonn Chanthou, is a grocer. The couple has three children. Two of the children are employed in a garment factory, while the other child is only two years old. His wife is shown in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers in order to make his crops more productive

loans.name: Kroem

texts.en:
Mrs. Kroem K. lives in Tuol Trea village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Mey Kun, is a fisherman.

Now Mrs. Kroem K.’s husband wants to expand his fishing by purchasing more fishing nets. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for her husband’s purpose. She hopes to increase their income and improve their family’s standard of living with this loan.

Mrs. Kroem K. is 43 years old and the mother of four children who are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more fishing nets for her husband

loans.name: Suleiman

texts.en:
Suleiman S. is an entrepreneur, a Tanzanian, and a married man. He has four school-aged children.

Suleiman runs a welding business at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. He receives orders for gates and windows from customers and makes and sells different types of gates for different customers. He purchases his business materials from the wholesale hardware shops at Kariakoo and also from other shops. The business income has enabled him to buy his own welding machine and to meet his family’s daily needs.

Suleiman is requesting a loan of Tsh 800,000 to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Armeda

texts.en:
Armeda V. is from the village of Libertad, Misamis Oriental. She is 70 years old. Armeda is widowed and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Armeda owns and operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling green bananas to the community. Armeda has been engaged in her business for over 40 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Armeda joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Armeda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Armeda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP. The money will be used to purchase new items to expand the number of products offered. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Armeda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing new items to expand the number of products offered

loans.name: Phea

texts.en: Mrs. Phea N. lives in Thorm Nei village in Takeo Province where she owns a plot of land upon which she cultivates rice. She also sells water lilies in the local market to earn more income for her family. Now she is applying for a loan to buy a buffalo for breeding. Mrs. Phea N. is a 52-year-old widow with four children, one of whom is employed in a Casino Club while another is a laborer and the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo for breeding.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This client is 35 years old, married, and has one child who graduated from high school.

The client has been working in his shop for more than fourteen years. Before establishing this shop he worked with a tailor to gain experience. However, he was eager to be on his own and decided to open his own business.

Now he needs a loan to purchase a new sewing machine and some cloth. He expect that his income will increase and he will raise his standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase cloth and a new sewing machine

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente G. is 50 years old and resides in Barangay Estefania Amulung, Cagayan. He is happily married and blessed with five loving children: Rovida, 31 years old and married; Reyfel, 27 years old and a graduate of an automotive course; Rexon, 17 years old and studying criminology; Rochavin, 12 years old and a sixth grade pupil; and Rovie, 10 years old and a fourth grade pupil. 

Vicente sells rice. His wife is a local vendor who sells different kinds of fruits and vegetables in their village. Since his wife does not have regular work, he started his own business as another source of income. Together they are helping one another to provide for their basic needs. Vicente wants to improve his business; consequently, he is asking to borrow PHP 7,000 from Kiva lenders. He plans to use the money to buy several sacks of rice and other commodities that he can offer to his customers.

loans.use: purchasing several sacks of rice and other commodities

loans.name: Nary

texts.en:
Mrs. Nary K. is a villager in Sam Chort village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who own 3-hectare (7.5-acre) field on which she cultivates rice.

In this plantation, Mrs. Nary K. faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil and it is far from the irrigation system. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a water pump, fertilizers, and pesticides to support the rice field.

Mrs. Nary K. is 45 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a bread shop while the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband, Mr. Rang Chhaom, is a technician and he is also a pig breeder. He is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a water pump, fertilizers, and pesticides to support her rice field

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam O. est âgée  de 45 ans, mariée mère de 7 enfants et vivant dans une famille polygame  dans le quartier Wala- Wala de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Pour des raisons sociales, elle n’a pas pu aller à l’école faire des études comme ses autres frères et sœurs de la famille. 
Afin de parvenir à satisfaire ses besoins, Mariam a commencé les activités génératrices  de revenus depuis son enfance auprès de sa mère et  exerce pour elle-même depuis  maintenant 15 ans.  
Elle est très bien connue  dans le secteur de la vente des condiments alimentaires  et  cette activité lui procure assez de revenus.  
Pour mener à bien sa vente enfin de satisfaire sa clientèle, elle n’a pas pris du temps à rejoindre  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 4 ans.  
Après  4 prêts  solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous payés correctement sans difficulté, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel, tous les deux précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter, plusieurs colis de différentes variétés de condiments alimentaires  à Sikasso et à Koutiala. Elle  effectue sa vente à son domicile à une clientèle essentiellement féminine, au comptant et quelques fois à crédit.   
Elle compte réaliser un  bénéfice  mensuel de  80.000 FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des d’intérêts du prêt, utiliser le bénéfice restant pour payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants et investir le reste  dans son  activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Mariam O., aged 45, is married and the mother of seven children living in a polygamous family in the Wala-Wala district of Koutiala prefecture (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  For societal reasons, she couldn't go to school to study, as did her brothers and sisters in the family.  To achieve meeting her needs, Mariam started a revenue-generating business with her mother when a child, and she has been working in it on her own for fifteen years.  She is very well-known in the sector of selling condiments, which is a business bringing in enough income for her. To carry out her sales in order to satisfy her customers, Mariam wasted no time in joining the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago.  After four solidarity loans (group loans), all repaid properly without a problem, she is now on her third individual loan.  The preceding ones have all been repaid.   She intends to buy several packets of different types of condiments in Sikasso and in Koutiala.  She sells out of her home to customers essentially of women, who pay in cash and sometimes on credit.  Mariam plans on realizing a monthly profit of 80,000 francs CFA that she envisions using to repay the loan interest.  The remaining profit will be used to cover the schooling costs for her children and to invest in her business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni is 29 years old and married with two children, one of whom is four and the other of whom is eleven. Both of her children go to school. She resides and rents a one room house in which she is staying with four people. She and her family have no access to electricity and no running water. They have only two meals a day. 

Zaituni works in a semi urban area in the outskirts of Kampala. She has a stall selling fish. She works seven days a week and receives an average of 30 customers a day; she sells to all sorts of people. Her major business challenges include the ever increasing price of fish and the rainy season, which reduces her number of customers. 

Her monthly expenses include feeding the family, medication and rent for her residence. She has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for five years. She is servicing her tenth loan. Regina joined MCDT because it was easy to work with and near her home. She wants to use this latest loan to buy more baskets of fish. She aspires to expand her business, to start going directly to fishermen, and to own an area in which she can permanently place her business.

loans.use: purchasing more baskets of fish

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia K. sells ground nut paste in the market and is requesting a loan to buy other items like beans, peas, maize flour, etc. to sell as well. Lucia is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a potter. She has 5 children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for children up to the university level.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and the empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchasing other items like beans, peas, maize flour, etc. to sell

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia is 39 years old and married with 5 children. Her husband is a commercial tailor. She sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She is a hard working woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty; in the future, she wants to own a supermarket. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN; with that money, she will purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thank you in advance to all of the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new goods, candy and children’s games for her shop

loans.name: Veth

texts.en:
Mrs. Veth E. is 38 years old and she lives in Trapaing Thmor village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns small piece of land on which she cultivates rice.

Mrs. Veth E.’s husband, Mr. Tong Se El, is a motorbike repairer. He is shown in the photo in front of a store. Now he wants to expand his business by purchasing a machine to clean his customers’ motorbikes. Thus, Mrs. Veth E. decided to request a loan for this purpose. She hopes to increase their income and improve her husband’s business.

This couple has two childrE., one of whom is attending the local school while the other stays at home to do housework.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for her husband to clean his customerss motorbikes

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Mariée,  mère  de 6 enfants, Madame Salimata  Konaté est âgée  de 34 ans et vit  dans une famille polygame avec son mari et ses enfants  dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala ( Région de Sikasso ).  
Elle n’a pas pu faire d’études dû à des raisons sociales, c’est pour cela qu’elle s’est  très vite intéressée aux activités commerciales de plusieurs sortes. Finalement Salimata opta pour la restauration, apprise auprès de sa maman. Elle exerce cette  depuis maintenant 7 ans. Elle est très bien sollicitée dans son secteur  surtout  les matins où elle est très fréquentée.  
Pour l’élargissement et l’amélioration de son activité, Madame Salimata Konaté n’a pas pris du temps à faire recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela depuis 4 ans.  
Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous payés correctement sans aucune difficulté, elle est à son 3ème  prêt  individuel et les deux précédents se sont bien dénoués.  
Avec ce nouveau financement, elle compte acheter, 5 sacs de haricot auprès des grossistes de céréales de Koutiala,  10 cartons de spaghettis et des condiments alimentaires. Elle vend du beignet à base de haricot et  bien d’autres plats alimentaires (haricot graines cuites, spaghettis etc)  devant sa porte  à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes , au comptant surtout.   
Elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de  100.000 FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des  taux d’intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso et participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de sa famille.
texts.en:
Madame Salimata Konaté is 34 years old, married and has six children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband and children in the Hamdallaye neighborhood in the Koutiala prefecture (Sikasso region of Mali). For socio-economic reasons she did not go to school, and so she became very involved with various commercial activities. Madame Konaté finally opted for the catering trade, which she picked up from her mother. She has done this for nearly seven years. She is highly sought after in her neighborhood, particularly during the morning when she is very busy. In order to develop and improve her business, Madame Konaté wasted no time in turning to micro-finance institution Solo Yiriwaso four years ago. After four group loans, all fully repaid without difficulty, she is now on to her third individual loan, the previous two having been successfully completed. With this new loan, she intends to buy five sacks of beans from the grain wholesalers in Koutiala, 10 cases of spaghetti and food condiments. She sells bean fritters and several other prepared foods (e.g., cooked bean seeds, spaghetti) in front of her house, to a clientèle of both men and women for cash. Madame Konaté hopes to generate a monthly income of 100,000 FCFA, which she will use to pay the interest to Soro Yiriwaso and to pay her daily household expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her catering business

loans.name: Seynabou

texts.fr: Seynabou S. est âgée de 24 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. elle vend de la glace et du pain.En même temps Elle travaille en collaboration avec son mari qui est tailleur. Elle achète une machine et ils se partagent la recette.  Son objectif est de participer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Seynabou S. is 24 years old, married, and the mother of two children. She sells ice cream and bread. At the same time, she works in collaboration with her husband, who is a tailor. She is buying a machine, and they share the income. Her objective is to help improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell ice cream and bread

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi is very hardworking; every single day, she makes sure that her family gets fed properly. She is 30 years old, married and has two children. She sells all kinds of drinks and food items. She has been a LAPO client for five years and has good record. She hopes to expand her business in future. She is requesting a loan of N 100,000; she will use the money to purchase more drinks and food items in bulk in other to make more profit and enhance her family's standard of living. Her children are doing well in school; her heart's desire is to educate them.

loans.use: purchasing more drinks and food items

loans.name: Usman

texts.en: Usman is a commercial tailor; additionally, he sells colorful sarongs and has a video and DVD rental stall. Thanks to these businesses combined, he hopes to be able to meet his family's basic needs. He is 40 years old and married with 2 children. His wife has a grocery stall that she uses to also improve the family's finances. Usman is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN so that he can purchase more sarongs, videos and DVDs. This is the high season for business and he hopes to make more of a profit. He says thank you in advance to all of the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing more sarongs, videos and DVDs

loans.name: Chreb

texts.en:
Mrs. Chreb S. lives in Pong Toek Choeurng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. She is also a duck breeder.

Since her poultry business is going well, Mrs. Chreb S. wants to expand it by purchasing six hundred more ducklings to raise and also duck food to earn more income.

Mrs. Chreb S. is 35 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the youngest one is just 3 years old. Her husband, Mr. Sout Mom, is a coconut seller. He is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To purchase 600 more ducklings as well as duck food

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro and his wife Merlinda reside in the village of Barangay Estefania, Amulung, Cagayan. Their main source of income is a motorcycle transport business. Additionally, Pedro is also engaged in farming, while Merlinda sells fruits and vegetables in their village to earn extra income. 

In order to further develop his transportation business, Pedro is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 from the Kiva lenders. He hopes that his loan request will be approved so that he can maintain his motorcycle transport and have his business grow and earn more of a profit.

Pedro and Merlinda are blessed with ten children who range from 5 to 26 years old.

loans.use: maintaining his vehicle and expanding his business

loans.name: Brigitte

texts.fr: Brigitte T. est une veuve de 57 ans, mère de 4 enfants. Elle vend de la boisson et souhaiterait améliorer son commerce. Son objectif est de soutenir ses enfants et d'améliorer leur condition de vie.
texts.en:
Brigitte T. is a widow, 57 years old, and the mother of four children. She sells beverages and would like to improve her business. Her objective is to support her children and to improve their living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell drinks

loans.name: Swalehe

texts.en:
Swalehe M. is a small-businessman, married with three school children. He runs a business buying and selling music CDs at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases the business goods from the wholesale suppliers and sells retail to his customers. His business income helps him to pay his children’s school fees and to capitalizing his business.

Swalehe is requesting a loan of Tsh 800,000 to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Khem

texts.en:
At the beginning of 2000, Khem T. built a small store in front of her home. In her shop, she sells a few grocery items to neighbors who live near her house in the village. In addition, she distills white wine for sale. She is 37 years old and the mother of three children. All three children attend high school and university. She is married to Kong Channarith, 43, an electrician. Khem T. and her husband are in the photo.

Recently, Khem T. sold all the items from her stock and she wants to replace her inventory to continue selling. Due to lack of funds, Khem T. has requested a loan from Kiva’s partner, HKL, to be used to buy a large number of grocery items to sell.

loans.use: To buy a large number of grocery items to sell

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Khady S. est une femme de 48 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle fait un petit commerce de citron, tomate, oignons et de l’élevage ovin. Avec ce prêt, elle voudrait augmenter son activité pour mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Khady S. is a 48-year-old woman who is married and the mother of five children. She has a small business selling lemons, tomatoes, and onions. And she raises sheep. With this loan, she would like to augment her work to do better in providing for her family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in a variety of foods and in livestock

loans.name: Sukuran

texts.en:
Sukuran S. is currently in the business of selling food in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase items like rice, sugar, beans, etc., to sell. Sukuran is 30 years old and is married to a businessman. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, beans etc. to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy some vegetable seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda M. is from the village of Upper Puntod. She is 53 years old, is married, and has eleven adult children. Erlinda owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2001, Erlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 15th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Kène

texts.fr: Kène F. est une femme mariée de 37 ans. Elle fait un commerce de mil, arachide, haricot et en même temps s’active dans l’élevage ovin. Son objectif est d’augmenter son commerce afin d’avoir une autonomie financière.
texts.en:
Kène F. is a 37-year-old married woman. She does commerce in millet, peanuts, and beans. And the same time, she is actively raising sheep. Her objective is to increase her commerce to have financial autonomy.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in millet, peanuts, and to raise livestock

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy has a bar in Nakulabye selling all types of beer. Her major business challenge is thieves. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys her goods near her home. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. Teddy works seven days a week. She serves an average of 30 customers a day and sells to all kinds of people. She has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for five years (now on her tenth loan).

Teddy is a 29-year-old married woman with two children, ages 3 months and 7 years. One of her children goes to school. She rents a two-room house where she lives with three people. Teddy doesn’t take care of any additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day. She has monthly residence and business expenses.

Teddy joined MCDT because it is near her home and is easy to work with it. She wants to use her loan to buy more crates of beer. She hopes to see her business grow. She wants to start going directly to factories and also hopes to own a permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer

loans.name: Eat

texts.en:
Mrs. Eat D. is a villager in Sam Chort village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. She also raises pigs.

Since her pigs have grown bigger and bigger, Mrs. Eat D. does not have enough money to buy pig feed for her pig business. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy pig feed and she will use the rest of loan to buy fertilizers to support her rice field.

Mrs. Eat D. is 63 years old and is a widow with two children, one of whom is employed in a bread shop while the other stays at home to do housework.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and to buy fertilizers to support her rice field

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov S. lives in Prey Kor Ky village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Khet Heng, is a motorbike taxi driver and is shown in the photo with her. This couple has four children, one of whom is a businessman while another is an electrician and the others are employed in a garment factory.

Now Mrs. Pov S. is applying for a loan to buy two calves to raise. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family standard of living with this loan after she sells them.

loans.use: To buy two calves to raise and sell

loans.name: Bassidi

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Bassidi   D. est âgé de 27 ans, célibataire  et père d’un  enfant.  Il vit avec plusieurs  co-locataires  dans une grande famille au quartier Darsalam de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Il a abandonné   l’école  en classe de 3ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour des raisons familiales. Il   mena alors plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus  entre autre (la vente d’habits, le métier de coiffeur etc.) Finalement il opte pour le secteur alimentaire. Aujourd’hui il possède deux rôtisseries et  un restaurant  depuis 10 ans. 
Son restaurant est situé dans le quartier populeux   de Darsalam près de l’hôpital central de Ségou et de la gare routière.   Il jouit d’une grande notoriété. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour faire face à la demande clientèle de plus en plus grandissante, il fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il  est à son 1er prêt individuel. 
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 400 litres d’huiles alimentaires, 15 kg de viandes (pour les steaks, les brochettes, les ragoûts) et 30 poulets. Il s’approvisionne sur place à Ségou.
Monsieur  Bassidi   D.   vend généralement au comptant et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de jeunes (femmes et hommes.)
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de créer d’autres activités génératrices de revenus. 
Son ambition est de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mr. Bassidi D. is a 27-year-old single father. He lives with a number of others in a large household in the Darsalam quarter of Ségou (the fourth largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali).

He left school in the third year of Elementary ("Ecole Fondamentale" in the Mali education system) for personal reasons, after which he had several paid jobs (selling clothes, and hairdressing, among others) before eventually opting for the food industry. He has been the owner of two rotisseries and a restaurant for ten years.

His restaurant is in the populous Darsalem quarter, near the Ségou central hospital and railway station, and has a great reputation. Concerned with raising enough funds to cope with increasing customer demand, he is approaching Soro Yiriwaso for his first personal loan. He intends to use this loan in order to buy 400 litres of cooking oil, 15kg of meat (for steaks, kebabs and stews) and 30 chickens. He sources them directly from Ségou.

Mr. D. generally takes cash, and often credit payments, from his mainly young (male and female) clientele. He envisages generating a monthly profit of 150 000FCFA which will enable him to invest in other money-making activities. His goal is to build a domestic house.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food ingredients for a restaurant business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 60 years old and married with 5 children. Her husband is a retired police officer. Mary sells drinks and groceries at retail prices to her customers and she aspires to be a major drink distributor in the future. She is a hardworking woman, working long hours to meet the basic needs of her family. She is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more drinks and groceries to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Felesa

texts.en: Felesa D. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 57 years old, is widowed, and has nine adult children. Felesa owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Felesa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Felesa is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Rejoice

texts.en: Rejoice is 32 years old and married with four children. She lives in Delta State, Nigeria. She sells bricks to help provide for the basic needs of her family. She requests a loan of NGN 80000 to purchase more cement and sand to mold more bricks to sell. Her business is booming and the loan will help her to expand it even more, increasing her earnings for the long run so she can better provide for the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase more cement and sand for moldings bricks.

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Mamadou Koné  est âgé de 29 ans, marié  et père d’un  enfant.  Il vit  dans une grande famille traditionnelle avec plusieurs autres ménages au quartier Darsalam de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).

Mamadou a abandonné l’école en classe de 3ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour des raisons personnelles. Il commença alors à apprendre  le métier de tailleur  auprès de son oncle et cela pendant 3 ans. 

Après cette phase d’apprentissage riche en expériences, il décida d’évoluer seul depuis maintenant 14 ans. Il jouit d’une grande notoriété due à son de génie de création de nouveautés.
En plus de cette activité de tailleur, Mamadou Koné fait également de temps à autres la commercialisation de céréales.

Dans le souci  de renforcer  son activité, il  a fait recours  au programme crédit de  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il  est à son 1er prêt individuel qu’il compte utiliser  pour acheter, 2 machines à coudre  de marque 20 U.  

Il  s’approvisionne sur place à Ségou. Monsieur  Mamadou   Koné fait ses prestations et vend ses habits au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de se prendre en charge (nourriture, habillement) et assurer les besoins de l’atelier. 
Son ambition est de faire du  stockage commercialisation de céréales à Ségou.
texts.en:
Monsieur Mamadou Koné is 29 years old, married, and father of one child. He lives in a traditional extended family with several other families in the Darsalam neighborhood in Ségou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mamadou abandoned his studies in the third grade of basic school (Malian educational system) for personal reasons. He then started to learn the tailoring trade alongside his uncle for three years. After this stage of his apprenticeship, during which he learned a great deal, he decided to branch out on his own; that was fourteen years ago now. He has a great reputation due to his genius for creating unique items. In addition to his tailoring business, Mamadou Koné also occasionally sells grain. In an effort to improve his business, he has turned to the loan program offered by the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is Mamadou's first individual loan, with which he intends to buy two 20U sewing machines. He buys his supplies locally in Ségou. He makes the clothes and sells them for cash or credit to both men and women. With this loan he hopes to generate a monthly income of 100,000 FCFA, which will allow him to take care of his expenses (e.g., food, clothing) and provide for the needs of his workshop. His ambition is to get into commercial grain storage in Ségou.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two sewing machines

loans.name: Jeremiah

texts.en: Jeremiah has a bakery where he bakes bread to sell at wholesale and retail prices. He is a focused, hard worker. He is 26 years old and single without children. He lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. He hopes to expand his business in the future by starting a catering school. He requests a loan in the amount of 180,000 NGN so he can purchase more bags of flour to bake more loaves of bread to sell. He is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of flour to bake more loaves of bread to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace L. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and maize flour and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.  Grace is 25 years old and is married.  Her husband is a car driver. They have two children who attend school.  With the extra profits she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

About BRAC:
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Ruyonza Ii Tukore Group, Ibanda

texts.en: Irene B. is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is 39 years old and married with children who attend school. Irene is a hardworking lady in the business of selling produce at the Ruyonza trading centre. Irene sells produce from both her own farm and from various farmers in her locality, depending on the quality. Since she started taking out loans, she has been able to earn 300,000 in monthly profits thanks to the loyalty of her customers. Her goal is to expand her business and to have a happy and healthy family. She needs a loan to help add more stock to her business to avoid shortages.

loans.use: Buying more produce for resale.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 26-year-old barber. Ahmad owns his barber shop in Ramallah city, Palestine. There is good demand for his services there. Ahmad uses some of his income to help his parents with their living expenses. The reason for the loan he is requesting is to improve his barber shop to offer better services. Let's do our best to help him.

loans.use: Improve his barber shop

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en: Luzminda M. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 65 years old, is widowed, and has five adult children. Luzminda owns and operates a business manufacturing and selling clay products to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over forty years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Luzminda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more chickens from far villages and sell them in town

loans.name: Kanou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kanou est composé de six  femmes dont une célibataire et cinq mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 36 ans, 5 enfants et  habitent dans le village Sébougou de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la république  du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage,  de parenté et font comme activités génératrices de revenus le commerce d’articles divers et la petite  restauration avec   les friandises.
Après six prêts de groupe tous correctement remboursés, elles sont à leur 7ème  prêt solidaire.
Ce nouveau prêt servira à acheter, des condiments alimentaires (concentrée de tomate, piment, oignon etc.) 1/2 sac de patate, 25 kg de farine de blé,  20 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe, 10grands sacs de charbon de bois, 20 tasses inoxydables de diverses qualités, 50 kg de riz pour les galettes et divers articles de  boutique (2 sacs de sucre, 1 carton de thé, 1bidon d’huile, 3 cartons de savon, 1/2 carton de lait.) 
Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments alimentaires au marché château de Ségou, avec les  forains de Loulouni, en tasses , en patate et  farine de blé  au grand marché, en bois de chauffe et en charbon  de bois  à Zambougou, les autres marchandises  telles  les articles  divers de  boutique sont achetés au marché de Médine. 
Les ventes sont généralement effectuées au marché de Sébougou, à domicile  et dans la boutique située non loin du pont du village, au comptant et ou à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 57.135 FCFA qui servira dans la prise des charges familiales,  à rembourser les intérêts du prêt et  à participer aux évènements sociaux.
Leurs ambitions sont : avoir chacune une maison à usage d’habitation, constituer le trousseau de mariage de leurs filles  et  assurer la pérennité de leurs activités commerciales car seul le  travail libère l’homme.
texts.en:
The Kanou Group is made up of six women, one single and five married, most of whom are in monogamous families. They are each around 36 years old, have five children each, and live in the village of Sébougou de Ségou (the fourth administrative region in Mali). They know each other as neighbors, fellow parents, and from working together in small businesses like selling various goods and catering sweets.

After six fully reimbursed group loans, this is their seventh request together. This new loan will be used to buy basic foodstuffs (tomato paste, hot peppers, onion, etc.), 1/2 a bag of potatoes, 25kg of flour, 20 cart-loads of firewood, 10 large bags of charcoal, 20 non-oxidizing basins, 50kg of rice for pastries, and other items for sale in their shops ( 2 bags of sugar, 1 box of tea, 1 drum of oil, 3 packages of soap, and 1/2 a box of milk.)

They stock up on basic foodstuffs at the Ségou market, their basins with the vendors in Loulouin, potatoes and flour at the main market, and firewood and charcoal in Zambougou. The other merchandise, such as the small shop items, are bought at the Médine market.

Sales are normally made at Sébougou market, in their homes, and in the shop near the village bridge. They sell for cash or credit to female and male customers. They hope to earn a profit of at least 57.135 FCFA a month, which will aid in paying off household expenses, reimbursing their loan, and participating in social events.

Their goals are to each have a house to live in, to amass a trousseau for their daughters, and to ensure the continuance of their commercial ventures, because only work liberates mankind.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various items for resale

loans.name: Augusta

texts.en: Augusta is a nurse by training. She also has a medicine stall, where she treats and sells medicines at retail prices to her customers. She has been selling medicines for a long time. She is 45 years old and married with five children. She is a focused, hard worker and she is determined to excel in her business and family life. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more medicines to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary P. is in the business of selling charcoal in the market and is requesting a loan to buy other items such as charcoal stoves and firewood to sell. Mary is 40 years old and is married with three children who all attend school. Her husband is a car driver. With the extra profits from her loan, Mary hopes to be able to open a retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy charcoal stoves and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a big cow that is ready to butcher.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 29 years old, single and has no children. She hopes to get married very soon. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.

Joy sells colorful sarongs at retail prices to her customers. She sells for long hours to ensure that there is food on her table to feed her aged parents. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profit. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. Joy hopes for a loan amount of 70,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Tabotsaneh Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Tabutsaneh group. This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. They have been in business for many years now but business has been developing at a very slow pace. They have thus come to SMT/Kiva to seek a loan of SLL 1,500,000 (or SLL 500,000 for each) to help them improve their businesses. 

Wurie T. in the middle is the leader of this group. Wurie was born in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. He is married with four children. Wurie’s wife is a petty businesswoman and his children are attending school -- one is in junior secondary school and the rest are in primary school. Wurie sells palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) and husk rice. He has been a businessman for eight years now. He will use this loan to buy husk-rice which he will clean and sell.

loans.use: Buy bags of husk rice

loans.name: Yelenkoura Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Yelenkoura comprend six femmes dont une célibataire, une veuve et quatre mariées dans des familles  monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans, 5 enfants et habitent dans le quartier Médine de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font toutes le commerce d’articles divers. 
C’est dans le souci d’augmenter le volume de leurs activités et de les diversifier qu’elles décidèrent de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Après six prêts solidaires correctement remboursés, le groupe Yelenkoura est à son 7ème  prêt de groupe.
Ce prêt  servira à acheter, des condiments alimentaires:( 4grandes boites de concentrée de tomate, 2 sacs de sel de cuisine, 1carton de cube maggi, 20 kg de graines de dah) ; des articles divers d’étalage (1sac de sucre, 1dizaine de sachets de thé prisé par les consommateurs, 4 cartons de savon de lessive, 1/2 carton d’anti-moustique en spirale) ; 40 sacs de charbon de bois; 4 sacs de petit mil, 1sac de poudre de pain de singe et des ingrédients pour la crème séchée. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments alimentaires et en divers articles d’étalage à Bamako, le charbon de bois est fourni sur place  les transporteurs de gros véhicules venant  de Fana, le mil, la poudre de pain de singe  et les ingrédients au marché de Médine.  
Pour faire de la crème séchée : il faut piler le mil  et le réduire en farine fine, faire griller une portion  de ce mil dépourvue du  son et bien lavée, on y ajoute du riz étuvé de la poudre de pain de singe tamisée plusieurs fois, plus  les ingrédients nécessaires réduits en farine, bien mélanger et faire sécher dans les conditions d’hygiène requises. 
Les graines de dah  sont transformées en « datou » utilisé dans nos sauces en remplacement du sounbala. 
Les ventes se font   à domicile, souvent livrée à domicile sur commande, aux marchés,  en détail, au comptant et  à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 55.000 FCFA qui servira à rembourser les  intérêts du prêt, à compléter le prix de condiments, à l’achat de fournitures scolaires, du savon et à participer aux évènements sociaux.
texts.en:
The Yelenkoura group consists of six women of which one is single, one is widowed and four are married in monogamous marriages. They are on average 45 years old with 5 children and live in the Médine district of the town Ségou (4th administrative area of the Republic of Mali.) They know each other from the neighborhood and family ties. They all do business with various goods. It is in the hopes of increasing and varying their business that they decided to work with the micro-finance non-profit Soro Yiriwaso.

After six repaid team loans, the Yelenkoura group is on to its 7th loan. This loan would be used to buy food condiments (4 large boxes of condensed tomatoes, 2 bags of cooking salt, 1 box on bouillon cubes, 20 kg of dah seeds) ; various goods to display ( 1 bag of sugar, about ten packets of tea that is highly regarded by their customers, 4 boxes laundry soap, 1/2 box mosquito repellent spirals); 40 bags of charcoal; 4 bags of millet, 1 bag of powdered baobab fruit and the ingredients for dried cream.

They supply themselves with the food condiments and various goods in Bamako, the charcoal is made on site, the carriers for large goods come from Fana. The millet and the powdered baobab fruit come from the market in Medine. To make dried cream: you must grind the millet to a fine flour, roast a part of this millet, remove the bran, and wash it well. To that we add oven-dried rice and powdered baobab fruit and sift it several times. Add the needed ingredients and reduce them to a flour. Mix well and let them dry in required hygienic conditions. The seeds of the dah are modified into "datou" used in our sauces instead of "sounbala."

The sales are done from home, in the from of house deliveries, at market, and retail by cash or credit. The customers are made up of both women and men. They hope to earn on average 55.00 FCFA monthly, which would repay the interest on the loan, cover the cost on the goods, the purchase of school stationary and soap, and enable them to participate in social events.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of varrious goods

loans.name: Akram

texts.en:
K. Akram is a good father, hard working, and steadfast in his endeavors as a farmer and in raising animals. Thanks to his wife’s assistance (pictured), he is able to care and feed the animals for sale later at both fairs and marketplaces in nearby towns. Traveling to nearby towns increases his costs, but that is offset by the higher asking price he gets there. For this reason, Akram and his wife take care to feed them properly in order to bring in more profit. Nevertheless, they would now like to increase the number of cattle. In order to buy cattle he needs a loan of $1500 USD and promises to be responsible and prompt in repaying it.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: http://www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her café business

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana is a widow with eight children. She is 58 years old. She takes care of her children alone. She sells ogogoro (local gin) at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She sells long hours to ensure that there is food on her table to feed herself and her children. She has been in this business for a long time. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. 

She hopes to sell her local gin at wholesale prices to her customers in the future. She hopes for the loan amount of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more local gin to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more local gin to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of fruits for her business

loans.name: Mirzorasul

texts.en:
Mirzorasul is married and has three children. He sells flour, macaroni, tea, coffee and other groceries in the local market. His vending stand is well known for the prices he offers and the affordability compared to market prices. Mirzorasul knows his customers’ preferences and always offers them the best quality in groceries. He has been selling goods for 10 years with consistent profits. Mirzorasul has been dreaming of opening a small grocery store for a long time. Now he is requesting for a loan of $1500 in order to increase the range of his selling goods. He has planned and envisioned the plans for expansion for his trade and believes that it will be truly helpful for his entrepreneurial endeavors. This loan will help Mirzorasul persist and take the necessary steps to achieve the success he has been dreaming of.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.  But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To expand the selection in his shop.

loans.name: Rosanna

texts.en:
Rosanna S. is a 34-year-old married woman from the town of Binalbagan, Negros Occidental.  She believes that if you love your family, you must do everything for their sake. This is the reason why she works so hard - to help her husband provide for the needs of their six children between ages 1 and 11.  The three oldest already attend school. Her aspirations are to provide a comfortable life for her family and send her children to school to prepare them for a better future.

To help her husband make their dream a reality, she started a general store.  Even with a small income, she knew she was helping her husband, so she continued her efforts and tried to offer more goods to her customers. To further increase her income potential, she started with a door-to-door vending business selling different kinds of root crops, vegetables, and fruits because these were abundant in her locality.

When demand for her goods increased, she realized that she needed additional capital just to be able to maintain enough inventory, so she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002. With the help of successive loans which she was able to pay off quickly, her business improved even further, and she was able to earn a net monthly income of PHP 18,000 on average. She has started to set aside some of her income for the future of her children.

For her 13th cycle loan she borrowed PHP 22,000 which was utilized as additional capital for her general store and door-to-door vending. Her loan was paid on a weekly basis and it was fully paid without any delay. Now she is borrowing for her 14th cycle, the amount of PHP 23,000, as additional capital for her business once again. The income she earns from it will be used to make improvements to her general store structure and as additional capital for her door-to-door vending.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To make improvements to her general store.

loans.name: Na We Say Group

texts.en:
Meet Adama K., Mamusu F. and Saffie M., members of the Na We Say Group. They are seeking their first loan, as a client group of SMT, for 1.5 million SLL (or SLL 500,000 for each). 

Adama is the group leader. She is approximately 49 and married with three children who attend school. Adama has owned her business for 15 years, and sells such goods as rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), and other assorted cooking supplies. With her new loan, Adama can expand her business inventory and increase the income she receives through her stall.

loans.use: To buy gallons of palm-oil.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina sells crates of drinks at wholesale and retail prices to her customers in Benin City, Edo state. She has a van that she uses to supply her customers. She is 43 years old and blessed with 7 children. Her children are doing well in school. Her husband is also involved in her business. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She hopes to become a major drink distributor in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional seeds and insecticides for her vegetable garden.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 40 years-old and married with seven children. Her children are in school and she hopes to give them a quality education. She sells drums that are used as storage for water and lubricants. She is the only person in her community that sells this type of drums. She is happy because the demand for her drums is high and she hopes to be able to meet the demands of her customers. Elizabeth has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more drums to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase storage drums.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret S. is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables in the market and is requesting a loan to buy other items such as groundnut paste and charcoal to sell. Margret is 38 years-old and is married to a plumber. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase groundnut paste and charcoal.

loans.name: Kokobeh Group

texts.en:
Here are Magret F., Aminata C., Salamatu D., Ramatu S. and M’Balu S.. They are small scale entrepreneurs in the township of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 2,500,000.00 (or SLL 500,000.00 each) to enable them to add more goods to their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and better profit. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing and academic pursuits.

Magret F., who is in the middle, is the leader of this group. She was born in Magburaka town about thirty-seven years ago. Magret is married with two children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending school – one is in senior secondary school III (SSS III) and the other is in Primary IV. Magret has been a businesswoman for fifteen years. She sells oil, flour and rice. She also sells fried food in one of the schools in Magburaka town. She will use this loan to buy gallons of vegetable oil, bags of flour and rice.

loans.use: To buy gallons of oil, bags of flour and rice.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda A. lives in the village of Brgy. Himaya, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She is 46 years-old, married, works as a farmer and a mother of eight children, seven of whom are attending school. The eldest child is already working. Belinda is striving hard to send her children to school and is doing everything she can to help her husband increase their family income to support their family. She hopes that someday through her hardwork, perseverance and dedication she can improve their living.

To achieve these dreams and make them a reality, she looked for a business where she could earn a good income to help support the needs of the family. At first, she bought one pig to fatten and sell, but she then realized that pig-fattening took three to four months to earn an income. In 2002, she joined Kiva partner NWTF-Project Dungganon to invest in farming. The loans that Belinda has received have been used in pig fattening and farm supplies. As the loans she was allowed to borrow grew, she bought farming equipment such as a hand tractor and a rice thresher to make the farming more efficient. Belinda has now been in business for more than seven years and she earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. She saves most of her profits for the education of her children, their household expenses and unexpected farm expenses.

Belinda's previous loan of Php 29,000 was used as additional capital for pig fattening and maintenance of her farm equipment. The loan was fully paid on-time maintaining her standing as a good member of NWTF-Project Dungganon. Now she is plans to borrow her 15th cycle loan in the same amount, of Php 29,000, to buy another rice thresher.

In the accompanying picture, Belinda poses near her hand tractor with her rice fields in the background.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional farm equipment (rice thresher).

loans.name: Valam

texts.en:
Valam is an entrepreneurial man and lives with his wife and three children who all help him in the business of production and sale of national bread “lepeshka”. He began his business to help with household expenses and at the same time to cover the costs of study of his children and their basic upkeep. He began his business five years ago by selling in both his house and on the market, counting already an almost fixed clientele. Valam is asking for a loan of $1500 to buy flour, coal and other products to increase the production of lepeshka in order to give better attention to his clients. Valam and his family thank you very much for the help which you give him in being able to follow through in creating his business and being able to continue with it in the future.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase flour, coal and other products for baking

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional maize for her business.

loans.name: Ehizogie

texts.en: Ehizogie is 24 years old and single without children. She sells sarongs,clothes, bags and shoes at retail prices to her customers in Benin City, Edo state.She hawks her goods within her community. She is a focused, hard worker that is determined to excel in her business. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs, bags and shoes to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs, shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty sells used clothes at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. The demands for her used clothes are high this season because there are lots of people in her community that cannot afford new clothes. She is 55 years old and married with six children. Her husband is a businessman. Her children are doing well in school and she hopes to give them a quality education. She hopes for a loan of N70,000 to purchase more used clothes to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional commodities such as tomatoes, dagaa, onions etc.

loans.name: Ekrema

texts.en: Ekrema is a 24-year-old, single young man living with his parents in Ramallah city of Palestine. He has a small computer repair shop. Ekrema is requesting a loan of $2,500 to buy computer parts in order to develop his work and, therefore, his income. He thanks you.

loans.use: To buy computer parts

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy owns a restaurant where she sells cooked foods and drinks. She manages the business to support her home financially. With the loan of N80,000, she plans to expand her business, which is now booming. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. ‘My customers patronize me because of the local dishes I prepare,' says Mercy. She is 30 years old, and married with 2 children. She lives in Delta State, Nigeria.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell
