loans.name: Hayfa'a

texts.en:
Hayfa'a is married with seven members in her family. She is a teacher in a public school and after work she helps her husband in managing their businesses.

Hayfa'a and her husband have a small grocery store and they also raise goats which they sell and also sell milk from them. Her husband used to work as a daily worker in Israel but because of the closure it became very hard for him to get there so they started these two businesses in addition to her work as a teacher.

This is Hayfa'a’s second loan from FATEN. For her first loan she took 3,000 USD and repaid it on time. Now she needs another 3,000 USD to buy feed for the goats and some products for the grocery store.

Hayfa'a’s husband appears in the photo with the sheep and goats.

loans.use: To buy feed for her goats and products for her grocery store

loans.name: Masombo Group

texts.en:
Mohamed T., Abib M., Neneh J., and Aminata J. are small-scale entrepreneurs in the town of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 2,000,000 SLL ($525), or 500,000 SLL each, to purchase more goods for their respective businesses. In this way, they will be able to generate more sales and, in turn, higher profits. Ultimately, the loan proceeds will enable them to better support their children in terms of food, clothing, and education.

Mohamed T. (pictured second from the left) is the leader of this group. Mohamed is twenty-three years of age, and was born in Magburaka town. He is single and has one child, who is not of school-going age. For seven years now, Mohamed has earned a living as a professional tailor. Indeed, he sews clothes for both male and female customers, and he sells his goods in and around Magburaka town. Mohamed will use this loan to buy sewing materials such as poplins, threads, zippers, etc.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials for the business, including poplins, threads, and zippers

loans.name: Shernazar

texts.en:
A. Shernazar raises and sells cattle. He is 23 years old, married and has two kids. He purchases cattle in the central market, feeds and cares for them, and then resells them at higher prices in the local market. Shernazar has been in this business for five years – thanks to his father who is a farmer and taught him a lot. He is an expert at choosing and caring for the animals. He gets up at five o'clock every morning to feed the cows and look after them. His knowledge and skills allow him to make his business successful, but his family is still quite poor because of the high prices they have to pay for everything.

Shernazar applied for a loan of $1500 US to purchase more cattle to expand his business. You could become an important part of his family's life. Shernazar deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her café

loans.name: Ahlam

texts.en:
Ahlam is a Palestinian hardworking woman and the mother of four children, one of whom is married.

Ahlam works in several businesses: she raises goats and sheep to sell and currently has more than thirty; she also has birds that she sells, either for food or for their lovely sounds; she even raises peacocks which she sells for their feathers.

Currently, after her husband became sick and was not able to work on a continuous basis, she decided to establish a greenhouse to grow and sell vegetables; she already has the land and the basic equipments in addition to the necessary experience.

Ahlam received several loans from FATEN and has repaid them all in full and on time. Now she needs 2,500 USD to start her greenhouse. She appears in the photo at her barn.

loans.use: To establish a greenhouse

loans.name: Utkirjon

texts.en:
B. Utkirjon always feels an immense satisfaction when people enjoy his delicious fruits and vegetables, since he puts an enormous amount of effort in each of his plantations. He possesses beautiful land which he cultivates for fruits and vegetables with his family, who are the reason for all the work he does. He is proud of his farm because it has allowed him to feed and educate his children. Utkirjon is aware of the needs of his family and for this reason he wants to open a grocery store in his house to cover part of the family’s daily expenses. In order to achieve this goal, he will use his loan to increase production of wheat and potatoes in season and to improve the crop quality.

Let's support Utkirjon’s intention to progress.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a large stock of fish for her business

loans.name: Sabanoh United Group

texts.en:
Hawa K., Marie C., Gbassay K., Kadiatu K., and Marie S. chose the name Sabanoh United for their newly-formed loan group. These borrowers are seeking a loan in the amount of 2,500,000 SLL ($650) via SMT and Kiva lenders to expand their businesses, increase their incomes, and improve their standards of living.

Hawa (pictured on the left) is the group’s leader, and she is a 53-year-old mother of nine children. Three of her children are on their own, while four of her children attend primary and secondary schools. For 31 years now, Hawa has been selling palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) to earn a living, and she hopes that her share of the group’s loan will allow her to expand this operation and increase her income.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional palm oil

loans.name: Bekzot

texts.en:
Bekzot has been farming since he was a young boy, and he now specializes in the cultivation of wheat and potatoes. He has 5 years of experience in this particular specialty, and he has been able to support himself by learning how to take care of and manage his crops during the short growing season. Bekzot is seeking this loan to purchase more farming products such as herbicides, fertilizers, and other necessities in order to appropriately manage his crops and, ultimately, to generate higher profits. Bekzot is 25 years old, and he is a very hard worker. He is single, and he does not have any children. Next year, after making a nice profit from his business, he is planning to marry to his loved one. You can play a big role in Bezkot's well-being by supporting him.

loans.use: To improve his business by purchasing various farming products (e.g., seeds, mineral fertilizer, and herbicides)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her café business.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael O. is 51 years old and he is married to Pamela who is a housewife. They are blessed with four children. The family lives in Magongo, Mombasa and Michael is a businessman there. He has been in the business of selling second-hand clothes and shoes for nine years now.

Michael was introduced to KADET by a friend and is glad to access his first loan. He intends to increase the stock of clothes and shoes with the money. Especially during the month of December, business booms with everyone wanting to buy new attire for the Christmas festive season. He actually asked for this loan to be able to target this demand for new stuff in his business and maximize on the profits.
 
He hopes to become a manufacturer and supplier of textiles in the future.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase clothes for selling.

loans.name: Nwanneka

texts.en: Nwanneka sells foodstuffs, and has been in the business for four years. She is very hard working. She assists her husband who is a civil servant.  She hopes to increase her sales. She is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell.  She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her children who are doing well in their school. She thanks you for your support. Nwanneka is 32 years old and married with three children.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna D. is so disappointed about her two elder children’s (22 and 18 years old) achievements in life. They were not able reach college and now they are having the kind of life they were born to have.  Being a mother, she wouldn’t want her children to remain poor for the rest of their lives. However, she can’t blame her children because, as parents, she and her husband should have supported the financial needs of their children, especially in school.  But because both of them have a very small income, it is impossible to support their children.

Despite what happened and the guilt felt, Lorna has been able to gather strength to move on and learn from her past experience. She told herself that it is not yet too late to help her children change their lives.

Now, she is requesting a much larger loan amount through ASHI and Kiva to sustain her tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) for hire business managed by her husband and eldest 22 year-old son, and also to grow her hog (pig) fattening business. The proceeds she will earn will enable her two youngest children to continue their studies until college. One is now 13 years old and the other one is 2 two years old.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for a hog fattening business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her genge business.

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla C. is from the village of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old. Perla is married and has 6 adult children. Perla owns & operates a business making & selling food The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked snack food in the local community. Perla has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2009, Perla joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perla is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional materials for the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Perla from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase additional materials for the business

loans.name: Azimkul

texts.en:
G. Azimkul is 42 years old. He is married and is the loving father of two children. Azimkul is a farmer. He is strong both physically and spiritually and plows the land to the best of his abilities. Thanks to his energy and high spirit, he has been able to support his family for six years and to offer them an education as well.

Azimkul sows wheat. Each year he grows sufficient crops for the consumption of his family and for selling. Now his business is stable, Azimkul believes that in future it will be the main income for him and his large family as his dearest children are growing up and accordingly, the expenses are rising too.

Today, Azimkul requests 4,000 Somoni in order to purchase seed and mineral fertilizer. He thanks everyone who trusted him and is supporting him today. He promises to repay the loan in a timely manner.

Be an important part of the growth of Azimkul’s business.

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en: Alicia U. has five loving children. Four of those have their own family now, while the youngest of ten years old still lives with her along with her husband, Bonifacio, and a four-year-old grandchild. Being poor, Alicia has nothing much for her child and grandchildren to inherit in the future except for the business she has been working hard at and the degree of education she can support until they can completely afford it. Because of this, Alicia tries to make her hog (pig) and cattle fattening business sustainable. Therefore she is requesting a loan to enrich her business little by little until her aspirations will be met.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and cattle for her fattening business.

loans.name: Arayik

texts.en:
Arayik M. is 27 years old and lives in Sevan. His specialty is being a service organizer in hotels and tourism complexes, but because of his living conditions he has never worked in this sphere. He worked as a shop assistant in a food market, then he had a shop where he sold mixed products, and a year ago he opened a butcher shop. Every month Arayik has approximately $415 in income from which he pays $104 for shop rental.

Arayik lives with his parents. His mother is jobless and his father helps Arayik in his business. Arayik supports his family, thanks to the income from his business which he hopes to expand in the future.

Arayik wants to receive a loan of 800.000 AMD to buy 6-8 calves to raise and sell.

loans.use: To buy 6-8 calves to raise and sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of drinks in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Junior's Group

texts.en:
This is Fatmata K., Ibrahim J. and Mariama K.. They named their group Junior’s Group, named after the leader’s son. They are small-scale businesspeople in Magburaka town, who want a loan of SLL 1,500,000.00 (or SLL 500,000 for each) to enable them expand their businesses. This will be their very first loan from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses so that they can attract more customers, make better sales, earn more profit and improve their living standard.

Fatmata K. (in the middle) is the leader of the group. Fatmata was born in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. She is twenty-five years of age. She is divorced and has three children and one foster child. Three of her children are attending primary schools and one is not of school age. Fatmata sells cooked rice and has been in this business for ten years now. She will use this loan to buy bags of rice, gallons of palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), and other cooking ingredients.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice, gallons of palm-oil and other cooking conduments

loans.name: Fares

texts.en: Fares, a 27-year-old father of 3 children who lives in Palestine, owns a small shop that sells vegetables and fruits. Fares requested a loan of 3,000 US dollars from Ryada in order to diversify the fruits and vegetables he sells in his shop. With your help, Fares will be able to move his business forward and offer his family a better future.

loans.use: Increasing of the variety of fruits & vegetables

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 34 years old and married with 5 children. She is a focused, hard worker. She sells for long hours to enable her meet the basic needs of her family members. She sells ice cream at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for her sales and she hopes to make more profits. She loves this business because it is highly competitive. She has been in this business for five years. She hopes for a loan of N60,000 to purchase more ice cream to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more ice cream

loans.name: Natalie

texts.en: Natalia T. skillfully faces challenges to bring her family out of the umbrella of poverty. Through loans she had requested from ASHI since her membership in 2007, she has able to finance several livelihood activities, which she has learned from her parents and others, such as cosmetology (manicure, pedicure, and haircutting), hog raising and native mat weaving (using palm tree leaf called “pandan” in Filipino) to earn money. At her age, now 74, it was hard for her to sustain her sources of income because she the sole provider for her 14-year-old daughter who is a high school student while she also helps some of her grandchildren and children who have their own families.

loans.use: Purchase piglets for fattening and finance her mat-weaving business.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis N. is 39 years old, married to Lucy Muthoni and they have four school-age children. He has been operating a welding workshop where he makes doors and windows from metal. He has been in this business in Naivasha town for the last 15 years. He does the doors and windows to clients' specifications and they are preferred to wooden doors for they offer some security.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. With this loan he plans to buy a new welding gun so that he does not loose business, especially since the demand for the metal doors and windows has gone up with the steady rise of real estate developments.

He has sees himself as a landlord in future by moving into the real estate business and to get there he soon plans to purchase a piece of land for this very purpose. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a new welding gun

loans.name: Mustafokul

texts.en:
H. Mustafokul is 37 years old. He is married with three adorable children. Mustafokul has been breeding sheep since he was a young boy. He is purposeful person. He likes animals and enjoys looking after them. Day by day he waits for his sheep to grow, watching the fruits of his investment with satisfaction. In order to house the new members of this small business, Mustafokul plans to improve the facilities of his farm and become better prepared in order to obtain better results by purchasing more sheep. That is why he is asking for a loan of $1500 USD. Let’s support this friendly man, who is a fine example of strength. Your contribution is very important.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of the sheep to expand the business.

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
After Perlita C. and her husband separated, her 14-year-old daughter and only child became the center of her life. Despite her low economic status, she still works hard to be able to accomplish her dream of giving her child a sustainable kind of life. For this to happen, she joined ASHI to have access to business capital to be able to practice her skill in cooking until she could develop an entrepreneurial skill. Eventually after her first full payment of her first loan, she acquired another loan and have had another business related to the previous one, which is fish selling and hog (pig) fattening. Once her pig is big enough, it will slaughtered by a relative and Perlita will sell its pork by the kilo to people in their village.

Because Perlita realized a lot of potential to become an entrepreneur and achieve her dream for her child, she is requesting a much larger loan. Through the loan she is requesting, she also hopes that she will discover more entrepreneurial skills and will fully develop an entrepreneurial attitude within herself.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients needed for her food production business and purchase rice and pig to slaughter and sell.

loans.name: Jebraeel

texts.en:
Jebraeel is married with three children and his wife owns a small restaurant that helps the family.

Jebraeel sells souvenirs in the street to tourists and has a license from the ministry of tourism to do this. He has been practicing this work for ten years. Bethlehem is a big attraction for Christians and where the nativity church is located he sells wood carving products, T-shirts, small gifts, etc.

Jebraeel needs the loan to buy new products as Christmas and the New Year are next month and it is the peak for selling such products.

Jebraeel appears in the photo at the FATEN office with some of his products.

loans.use: To buy goods for the Christmas and New Year season

loans.name: Edelyn

texts.en:
Edelyn T. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old. Edelyn is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Edelyn owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling daily products such as shampoo, sardines, biscuits, candies and sugar in the local community. Edelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Edelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and give her the ability to engage in business activities. Edelyn is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Edelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sherly

texts.en:
Sherly E.’s business is not only supporting and sustaining the needs of her family but also her fellow small entrepreneurs in their village in a very remote municipality of Libertad in Antique province. Through a loan and the proceeds from her hog (pig) fattening business, she has been able to buy native mats manufactured in their village and bring them to market for sale. If she is not contented with her daily sales turnover in the market, she goes to other municipalities on their scheduled market day to sell.

Without much training, Sherly has able to develop an entrepreneurial skill and attitude within herself through practical experience, just like other poor women. She is determined to change their standard of living so that her 17-year-old only child can graduate from college. She will never surrender to the challenges poverty will bring her. Through loans she can access from ASHI and KIVA, she will be have an opportunity to grow and expand her hog fattening business until she has a piggery.

loans.use: Will be used to purchase piglets and food for fattening.

loans.name: Suzan

texts.en:
Suzan is 34 years old and married with four children. Her children are all in school except for the youngest, who is not yet of school age.

Suzan sells cooked foods, drinks, and rechargeable phone cards. She has been in this business for two years. With the combined businesses, she is able to support her family’s basic needs and other necessities.

She is requesting a loan of N60,000 to purchase more foodstuffs, drinks and rechargeable phone cards. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs, drinks and rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 29 years old and married to Virginia Njambi. They have a five-year-old child.

David operates a barber shop in Naivasha. He has been in this business for the last three years and has a steady and loyal customer base. He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy a new shaving machine to replace the one he currently uses. In the future, he plans to buy a power saw so that he can open a workshop where he will render services using the power saw.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. You can obtain more information on KADET from the website www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: To buy a shaving machine

loans.name: Sesay United Group

texts.en:
This is Foday S., Idrissa K., and Isatu S.. They are local entrepreneurs in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They named their group S. group, after the surname of the group’s leader. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, they will be able to make enough profit to repay the loan, feed their children, pay their school fees, and save some money for unforeseen situations.

Foday S., shown in the middle of the photo, is the leader of the group. Foday was born in a village called Batkanu, in northern Sierra Leone. He is forty-one years of age. He is married to a businesswoman and they have three children. Two of their children are in primary school and the last is in nursery school. Foday sells local produce like palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), rice, soap and so on. Foday has been a businessman for two years now.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Uche

texts.en:
Uche is 30 years old and married to Mr. Ezeadiefe Ike. She owns a cosmetics and groceries store. She sells items like lipstick, nail polish, bathing soap, tea, milk, etc. She is hardworking; she assists her husband and any other person when the need arise.

Uche has been a LAPO client for 2 years with good repayment history. She hopes to increase her sales, so she is requesting a loan of N150, 000 to purchase more cosmetics and groceries to sell. She says thanks to LAPO.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics and groceries to sell

loans.name: Mustafokul

texts.en:
T. Mustafokul is 51 years old, married and has two children. Mustafokul was born and raised in Shahristan, Tajikistan, where he has grown up cultivating wheat and different kinds of vegetables. He has worked for agriculture for 20 years and gained much experience. His family helps Mustafokul with his business.

Mustafokul hopes to invest a loan of 8500 TJS in buying seeds and fertilizer for the upcoming planting season of wheat. Mustafokul feels that with the loan he can earn more to make his dreams come true. With your collaboration he’ll be able to improve his living conditions.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas is a 41-year-old married woman with 5 children. To earn a living, she sells foodstuffs, drinks, and cooking oil at retail prices to her customers. She explains that she sells her various products for long hours to ensure that she can put food on the table in order to feed her immediate family. She has been in this business for a long time.

She is now seeking a loan in the amount of N70,000 ($425) to purchase more foodstuffs and cooking oil for resale purposes. Indeed, this is the high season for sales, so she hopes to generate higher profits by satisfying the increased customer demand. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To meet customer demand by purchasing additional foodstuffs and cooking oil

loans.name: Said

texts.en:
Y. Said is 50-year-old married man with four children. Said is a hard-working man. He knew many people who purchased cattle, and this motivated him to start his own business nine years ago. Over time, he has increased his cattle sales and he is proud to say that the business has been running well, but he now needs additional capital to expand his business. Therefore, Said is requesting a loan in the amount of 4000 Somoni to purchase small cattle and fodder for them. He and his family thank you very much for the support that you offer them in helping to expand his business and helping them give their children a better quality of life.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase small cattle and fodder for them.

loans.name: Kagongi Tukwatanise, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
N. Didas is a 24-year-old male and the leader of his lending group in Ibanda. Didas is married with one child and he takes care of two additional dependents, all of whom are in school. He has a retail shop. He has been a shopkeeper in Kagongi trading center for one year and so far he has been able to make some little profits that help him run his home.

This is his first loan with his lending group, and being loyal to his customers has done wonders for him. In future, Didas needs to turn the shop into a wholesale business so that he can make more money out of it. He also hopes for a stable and self-sustaining family. He needs a loan to help buy more stock for his shop to avoid shortages. He is a well-behaved and determined man with a strong drive to succeed.

loans.use: To restock his retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: Madel

texts.en:
Madel B. is from the village of Balanlinao, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 23 years old. Madel is married and has three small children. To make a living, Madel owns and operates a business selling hot cake snacks in the local community. Madel has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $50 month from these activities.

In 2009, Madel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Madel is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase ingredients for food making. This will be her 1st loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated expand her business and for family needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for food making

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is excited to take his first loan with Kiva. He will use this loan to invest in his business of selling cosmetics and baby wear which he will buy in bulk to get a better price. He hopes that this loan will help him build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for his family. Joseph has been in this business for eight years. He is currently taking a part-time course in one of the higher institutions. In order to make more profit and to complete his education, he is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more cosmetics and baby wear to meet with customers' demands in this festive season. He also needs to increase his capital and his profits. Joseph is 28 years old.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics and baby wear to sell

loans.name: Ochilboy

texts.en:
Ochilboy has a very large family. He is married and living with his parents. Ochilboy has been running his farming business for seven years. He is a very good family man, so he loves his family and wants a good future for them. He is dreaming of having his own children and of giving them a good education so that someday they’ll become successful entrepreneurs. His beloved wife does whatever she can to help him, and together they have decided to increase the number of crops they plant so that they can generate a larger income. They will invest this loan in purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer for the upcoming wheat-growing season. In order to do this, Ochilboy is requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni. He appeals to your generosity so that he can begin this family project. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Unchangeable Group

texts.en:
Gladys F. is a leader of a group of 5 borrowers called Unchangeable. She is 40 years old, married with 4 children ages 11 to 22 years old and their educational levels are 10th grade to high school graduate.  Gladys also cares for 2 siblings.  She is a 7th grade dropout due to poverty.

Gladys and her family live and work in the Duala community, a community that has one of the largest food markets in Monrovia, north of the capital Monrovia, Liberia.  Her business is the sales of plastic materials and clothing.  She buys plastic materials and clothing from importers and sells retail in the Duala market, north of the capital Monrovia, Liberia.  She has been running this business for 18 years and is hoping to improve to being an importer.

Gladys talks to her customers in a good manner and sells quality goods in order to encourage customers to continue patronizing her business, but she started by selling palm oil with LD $200.00, which was given to her by her father. 

She needs this loan to purchase more clothing so that she can serve her customers.  Gladys dreams of giving her children better educations and building a house.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes so that she can serve her customers.

loans.name: Josef

texts.en:
Josef is married with four children and his business is the only source of income for his family.

Josef has operated his workshop for fifteen years; his father used to work in it. He makes souvenirs from olive wood. He makes crosses, grottos, and many other souvenirs for Christians. He sells them to retail shops and merchants who export them to the U.S. and Europe. He appears in the photo at his workshop.

This is Josef’s second loan from FATEN. He has requested 2,000 USD to buy olive wood as now is the best time to buy it after the olive harvest.

loans.use: To buy more olive wood

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her café business.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel is 52 years old and married with six children. She sells sarongs and tailoring materials. She is also a tailor. She makes lovely designs for her customers. Her greatest joy in her business is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to own a fashion institute in the future. This is the high season for her business and she wants to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes for a loan of N120,000 NGN to purchase sarongs and tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and tailoring materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase materials for making mats.

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en: Modesta is 30 years old, married and has two children. She has been in LAPO, a Kiva partner, for four years. She repays her loan when it is due and is a committed client. She sells cosmetics and has been in the business for some years. She manages the business with her husband, who is now into a motor spare-parts business. Modesta hopes for a big store in the future. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase cosmetics in bulk as this attracts a discount and increases her profits. She says thank you to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita V. is from the village of Guba Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old, widowed and she has 4 adult children.

To make a living, Anita operates single motorcycle transportation services. Anita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Anita joined GDMPC to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita successfully repaid her first loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting her second loan of 15,000 PHP which she will use to repair existing vehicles for better service.

Anita plans to use the additional revenue to improve her family’s general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note
To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicles for better service.

loans.name: Judith Adhiambo

texts.en:
Judith Adhiambo is 29 years old, married to Alphonce and a mother of two children, aged seven and one. She sells cereals in Kondele, an open air populous market in the outskirts of Kisumu City.

Judith went into this type of business seven years ago, when both of her parents died in quick succession (within a period of 3 months). She had to drop college in her final year for there was no one to pay for her college fees. She used the funds contributed by mourners as her initial capital.

Judith was introduced to KADET Ltd by a friend from the market, who encouraged her to join her group. This is her sixth loan. She intends to use the money to purchase more stock of beans, groundnuts, millet and cassava during this harvest season for stocking.

She aspires to go back to college and complete her diploma course in Management Information Systems because she had only one unit left when she dropped out. She also aspires to see her children get a good education, because she feels that this is the best gift she can offer them.

About KADET

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their families across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase stock of cassava, beans and groundnuts.

loans.name: Madiha

texts.en:
Madiha Taqatqa is married and her husband is the one managing their business. He owns a taxi that he operates between Bethlehem and Zatara village. He used to work inside Israel but since the separation wall, it became impossible for him to get there and also he was not able to get a permit. So he bought the taxi and works with it.

This is the family’s second loan from FATEN and they need this loan to do some maintenance on their taxi and to pay some registration fees to the Transportation Department.

Madiha and her husband appear in the photo next to their taxi.

loans.use: To pay for taxi maintenance and registration fees

loans.name: Pauline Akossiwa

texts.fr: K. Pauline Akossiwa est née en 1979 à Athiémé, non loin de la frontière du Togo, pays voisin du Bénin. Pauline Akossiwa est mariée à GBEKE Christophe, un agent commercial. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Pauline Akossiwa vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son conjoint au quartier Cocotomey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis huit ans. Pauline Akossiwa vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Ayant arrêté l'école au cours primaire, Pauline Akossiwa exerce le métier de coiffeuse depuis six ans déjà. A côté de cela, Pauline Akossiwa vend des mèches et des produits cosmétiques dans son atelier se trouvant à Cocotomey. Pauline Akossiwa a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit à ALIDé qui a été bien remboursé. En vue d'accroître son activité et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Pauline Akossiwa sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
K. Pauline Akossiwa was born in 1979 in Athiémé, not far from the border of Togo, a country neighboring Benin.  She is married to GBEKE Christophe, a commercial agent.  The couple has two children who are all in school.  For eight years, Pauline Akossiwa has been living in the Cocotomey district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, where she still does, together with her children and husband.  She comes to her husband's aid in meeting family expenses.  Having dropped out in primary school, she has been working in the hairdressing trade for six years already.  Aside from this, she sells hair extensions and cosmetics in her shop located in Cocotomey. She has benefited from an ALIDé loan before, which has been repaid.  With the aim of growing her business and satisfying her customers further, she's requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 boxes of cosmetics and 3 dozen hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her café business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Mirembe Women's Group Of Mukono

texts.en: Robinah M. is 51 years old and the leader of her group in Mukono. She cares for one orphan in addition to her six children.  Robinah has been a brickmaker for 7 years and generates 200,000 USH per month from her business. She hopes to be able to expand her business with the loan and to be able to continue paying for her children’s education.

loans.use: Expansion of Business

loans.name: God Is Great Group

texts.en:
On the photo are members of the God is Great group. They are local entrepreneurs in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. This is not the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT/Kiva Lenders. With the help of previous SMT/Kiva loans, they have been able to improve their businesses, make better sales, and consequently improve their living standards. With the profit they made, they were able to better look after themselves and their children. They use the proceeds they make to pay for their children’s school fees. They also use it to feed and clothe themselves and their children. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are again asking for a new loan of SLL 1,200,000 for each to further strengthen their businesses.

The leader of this group is Mariama S. M. (on the left). Mariama is approximately thirty-six years of age. She was born in Port Loko district, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a businessman and they have five children. Three of Mariama’s children attend school (Junior, Secondary, and Primary school). Mariama sells ready-to-wear-clothes for both children and adults. She has been a businesswoman for six years now. Mariama will use this loan to buy more clothes to add to her current stock.

(Attached on the right is a group member who was not present for a snap shot)

loans.use: Buy additional clothes to sell

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji L. is currently in the business of selling bread and tea and is requesting a loan to buy crates of soda and water to sell. Keji is 28 years old and is married with a husband who is a soldier. She has one child who does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy crates of soda and water to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her café business

loans.name: Ala'

texts.en:
Ala' is a Palestinian young man who works as a police officer in the Palestinian National Authority. He earns a small monthly salary that doesn't meet his monthly expenses, especially since he just got married and owes some money to some of his friends and family.

Ala' decided to take a loan from FATEN to cover all his debts so that he can repay in accordance with his income.

Ala' appears in the photo at the FATEN office.

loans.use: To pay his debts

loans.name: Bugaga Bagalaga Of Mukono Group

texts.en:
Mayi S. is 35 years old and is the leader of her group in Mukono. She is married with three children who are all currently enrolled in school.

Mayi has been running a business as a butcher for one year and attributes her success thus far to the clean meat she offers her customers. She would like to use her loan of 200,000 USH to buy more meat.

With continued hard work and success Mayi one day hopes to transition from being a butcher to owning a retail operation.

loans.use: To buy more meat

loans.name: Kerr-Them-Go Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Kerr-Them-Go group. They are small scale entrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of Le 500,000 for each to enable them to add more goods into their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and better profit. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing and in their academic pursuits. 

Adama K. (right) is the leader of this group. She is 35 years of age, born in a place call Pat Kanu located between Makeni and Freetown (the capital city). She currently resides in Makeni, together with her husband and four children. Two of her children are already grown-ups and are on their own, the other two are too young to attend school. Her husband is a motor driver, plying the Makeni-Freetown highway. Adama is a businesswoman who sells cooked rice, meat and vegetables. She has been a businesswoman for many years now. With this loan she will buy cooking ingredients in wholesale.

(Attached on the left is a group member who was not present for a group snapshot).

loans.use: Buy cooking ingredients like rice, palm-oil, tomatoes etc.

loans.name: Queen

texts.en: Queen is 28 years old and single without children. She is a hard-working woman. She hopes to get married very soon. She loves cooking and that is why she commercialized her cooking skill by owning a restaurant where she sells drinks and cooked foods. The demand for her cooked foods in her community are high and she hopes to meet the demand of her customers. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more chairs and tables for her customers and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, chairs and tables

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel M. is 32 years old and married to Veronicah M.; they have three school-aged children.  He has been selling clothes in Naivasha town for one year now.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan after having repaid his first loan. He plans to stock more children's clothing, especially as this is the peak season for sales. 

His future dreams are to open a wholesale shop that will sell household goods and farming products.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria is 34 years old and married with a child. She is a focused, hard worker. She makes and sells soaps at wholesale and retail prices to her customers in Benin City, Edo state. The demand for her soap is high and she hopes to meet the demand of her customers. She hopes for a loan of N30,000 to purchase more materials to make more soap to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for making soaps

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for making local beer.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan T. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Juan is 23 years old and is married with a husband who is a shopkeeper. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school by paying school fees.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anwar

texts.en:
Anwar is a young Palestinian man who is married and has small children.

In Palestine, butcher shops buy chicken live from the farms and at the shop they prepare it for their customers. They take off the feathers in order for the meat to be fresh since the people here buy the meat or the chicken fresh and slaughtered on the same day.

Anwar has operated his shop for ten years selling both chickens and eggs. There is good demand for his shop, especially since he has contracts with some Bethlehem hotels and restaurants.

Anwar appears in the photo at his shop.

loans.use: To buy products for his shop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice sells various kinds of foodstuff and drinks; she has been in this trade for the past three years. This she does to meet her daily needs. She is very hard working. 

She hopes to increase her sales, make more profit that will enable her assist her husband in supporting the family and pay for the children's education. She hopes for loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell. She says thanks for the support. Her greatest problem is the power supply.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of cosmetics in bulk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional accessories and cloth.

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en:
Magdalene sells drinks, toiletries and gift items at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to meet the demand of her customers. She is a hard-working woman, and she hopes to excel in her business.  She is married with three children. She is 46 years old. She lives in Edo State, Nigeria. 

She hopes for a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more gifts items, toiletries and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more gifts items, toiletries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina N. sells soap, biscuits and sundries at a shop.  She is requesting a loan to purchase bags of sugar and beans and other items to sell.  Edwina is 28 and married to a businessman. She has 6 children, who are going to school.  With the extra profits resulting from the loan, she hopes to open another shop for wholesale.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services.  These are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest non-governmental organizations, as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of sugar and beans and other items to sell

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 30 years old. He sells drinks and fried meat. Patrick is hard-working and is seeking a loan to help him meet increased customer demand during the holidays.  One of his greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction he is able to have with her customers.

He is seeking a loan of N150,000 to purchase larger quantities of drinks at a discount.  Patrick plans to use the increased profit generated by the loan to support his family.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Jalal

texts.en:
Jalal is a Palestinian man who is married with three children. He operates a clothing shop and an olive-wood workshop where his wife helps him. He has had the clothing shop for one-and-a-half years and it works very well.

Jalal has requested 2,000 USD from FATEN to buy new goods for his shop, since Eid al Adha (a Muslim feast) is next week and also Christmas and New Year are next month.

Jalal appears in the photo at his store.

loans.use: To buy goods for his shop

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 40-year-old single mother of two teenage boys. She has run the Brown Skin Beauty Clinic since 2004 in the Kayole area of Nairobi. She offers manicures, pedicures, and hairdressing for men and women.  Beatrice employs one person and she describes herself as very successful.

Beatrice has requested a loan of Kes. 50,000 through Kiva's field partner, Faulu, to add stock to the salon.

Beatrice says that she has developed her business from very humble beginnings.  She dreams of expanding into more businesses in the future.

loans.use: Purchase stock for beauty salon

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her café business.

loans.name: Abau

texts.en:
Abau R. is currently in the business of selling charcoal in the market, and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal to sell.  Abau is 35 years old and is married to a soldier. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcaol to sell

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a young Palestinian man, 27 years old, who is married with three children. He operates a grocery shop where he sells vegetables, canned food and candy.

Mohammad has requested 2,000 USD from FATEN to buy new products and vegetables for his shop.

Mohammad appears in the photo at his shop.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and products for his shop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is 38 years old and married with four children. She sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She works long hours to meet the basic needs and necessities of her family. She has been in this business since 2003. She hopes for a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more drinks and groceries to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and groceries to sell

loans.name: Rachelle Jeanne

texts.fr: B. Rachelle Jeanne est née en 1970 à Sakété au Bénin. Mariée à DOSSOUMOU Eric, un dépaneur, Rachelle Jeanne est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. En plus des deux enfants, Rachelle Jeanne a un autre enfant en charge. Rachelle Jeanne vit avec son conjoint et ses enfants au quartier Cococodji, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis huit ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Rachelle Jeanne n’a jamais été à l’école. Depuis cinq ans, Rachelle Jeanne mène comme activité, la vente de sacs de maïs, de soja et de haricot au marché de Cococodji. Rachelle Jeanne fait ses approvisionnements à Parakou, au Nord du Bénin. Rachelle Jeanne a déjà obtenu un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Rachelle Jeanne désire agrandir son activité, et ouvrir un magasin de stockage et un second stand de vente de ses produits. C’est pourquoi, Rachelle Jeanne sollicite un second crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
B. Rachelle Jeanne was born in 1970 in Sakété in Bénin.  Married to DOSSOUMOU Eric, a repairman, she is the mother of two children who are all in school. In addition to the two, she has another child in her care.  For eight years, Rachelle Jeanne has been living with her husband and children in the Cococodji district, not far from  Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  The couple is covering family expenses jointly.  Rachelle Jeanne has never been to school.  For five years, she has been running a business selling sacks of corn, soybeans, and beans at the Cococodji market.  She stocks up in Parakou, in northern Benin. She has had an ALIDé loan before, which she repaid.  She would like to expand her business and to open a storehouse and a second stand to sell her goods.  This is why she's requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 4 sacks of corn and 4 sacks of soybeans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more fish for her business.

loans.name: St. Suzanne Jesus Devant Group

texts.en:
The “Jesus Devant” Group, which translates from Haitian Creole to “Jesus in Front”, consists of ten female entrepreneurs. After successfully repaying their first and second loans, they are looking forward to continued success and growth in their businesses with their third loan.

Alteon P. is one of two representatives of the group. He is a husband and father to seven children ranging in ages from 13 to 3 years old.

This hardworking dad focuses his business efforts on charcoal sales. He will sometimes buy the charcoal already made but when possible he simply buys the wood and makes the charcoal himself, thus increasing his profit margin. He also dabbles in the sale of syrup which he buys when he buys freshly cut wood.

Alteon is thankful for the past loans because he was able to send his children to school, feed his family better, and create savings with the increased profits. He prays that he will be able to grow his business and that “Esperanza may continue to grow and be a blessing to the community.”

On behalf of Alteon, Jesus Devant, and Esperanza we thank you for your support.

loans.use: To buy charcoal, wood, syrup, and bags for charcoal transportation

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia T.  is currently in the business of selling fresh green vegetables in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase pulses (beans, peas, groundnuts) and maize flour to sell.  Lucia is 40 years old and is a widow.  She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase pulses and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional ingredients for her café.

loans.name: Ikechuku

texts.en: Ikechuku is excited at the prospect of securing his first loan from Kiva. He is 35 years old, married, has two children and makes a living selling groceries and food items. He has been in the business for three years, and uses his profits to care for his family. He hopes to increase the size of his business in future, and will use this loan for N100,000 to buy more groceries and food in bulk to sell to his customers.

loans.use: To buy more groceries and food to sell

loans.name: Silvester

texts.en: Silvester is a 36 years old and the father of four children between the ages of two and 14. He runs the Lucky Summer Kerosene Pump Shop, where he sells general household items. He also takes on painting jobs as a source of extra income. Silvester has had his shop for three years and is widely thought of as hardworking and determined. He has applied for this loan for $275 to buy sugar and eggs to sell to his customers. In the future, he hopes to expand his business into a wholesale supply company so that he can live a comfortable life with his family.

loans.use: To buy sugar and eggs to sell to his customers

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is a 55-year-old widow with eight children who lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She cares for her children on her own, and hopes above all to give them a good education. She makes a living selling groceries, drinks and food. She has been in this business for many years, and hopes to earn a good profit during the current high season. Helen has applied for a loan for $350 to buy more drinks, groceries and food to sell to her customers, and extends her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more groceries, drinks and food to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional goods to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en: Sylvia N. is 42 years old, married with five children ages 9 and 23 years.  All her children go to school. She owns a two room house where she is staying with seven people.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.  Sylvia has a stall in her home in Kyebando selling all types of snacks.  Her business is in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. Sylvia incurs transport costs going to and from shopping at the  Kalerwe market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city.   She works seven days a week and serves an average of 35 customers a day.  Her major business challenge is thieves. Sylvia has been in this business for over twenty years and with MCDT for  eight years servicing her twentieth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more cooking oil, baking flour, a sack of Irish potatoes for chips and other commodities.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil, a sack of irish potatoes,baking flour and other commodities

loans.name: Lona

texts.en:
Lona S. is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is a primary school teacher. She has 3 children who go to school.  Lona S. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more brewing materials for her breweries. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase more brewing materials for her breweries

loans.name: Andeline

texts.en: Andeline O. is 34 years old and the mother of 6 children. She lives in Delta State, Nigeria. She sells groceries and foodstuffs to make a living. Anderline has been with LAPO for seven years and she is a faithful and a committed client.  Andeline hopes for a loan amount of N80, 000 to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to meet customer demand and to make more profit.  One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan O. is 45 years old, married with 6 children. Her husband is a commercial driver. She is a hard working woman. She sells foodstuffs and soup ingredients at retail prices to her customers.She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. Susan is requesting a loan amount of 70,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco B. is 50 years old and lives with his partner, Mary, who is 30 years old. They have three sons who are 9, 7 and 4 years old. 
Francisco has sacrificed a lot for his farm. He cultivates vegetables (lettuce, chard, parsley, etc.). He started working there when he was very young. His father owned a family orchard and Francisco had to help with the daily work. Francisco only has a 6th grade education. He comes from a big family and  had 7 siblings, all of whom worked in the family orchard. 
Today, thanks to their effort and the support of his family, Francisco’s farming business grows more and more. There are very few producers in their area, so Francisco’s produce commands high demand. 
Francisco is very happy with his work and earnings, because it allows him to continue to  have a comfortable home, two vehicles and gives him enough profit to provide for his family. 
Francisco is looking for a loan to use to purchase fertilizer and pesticides for his farm. He wants to increase the yield at the next harvest.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Ndibanye

texts.en: Ndibanye J. I. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and married woman. She runs a shop at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. She sells a variety of foodstuffs such as wheat flour, maize flour, beans, sugar, and cooking oil. She purchases the goods from wholesale shops and sells the items to retail customers. The business income meets her daily family demand and provides capital for her business. She is requesting a loan of 800,000 TZS to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to expand her business

loans.name: Angella

texts.en:
Angella is 42 years old and married with six children, aged between 15 and 23 years. All of her children go to school. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she is staying with four people. Angella takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water, and gets three meals a day. She doesn’t incur transport costs to and from shopping as she buys from her place of work in Nakawa market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city. She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala.

Angella works seven days a week. She receives an average of 35 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both in wholesale and retail. She has a stall selling bananas in Nakawa Market. Her major business challenges are thieves and the ever-increasing prices of bananas due to persistent drought in many villages of Uganda. She has been in this business for over ten years and with MCDT for eight years, currently servicing her twentieth loan. Besides this banana business, she also sells beer at her home. Angella joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas and crates of beer. She is aspiring to go to the villages to sell directly.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas and crates of beer

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is 55 years old and married with three children. Her husband is an electrician.

Rita sells groceries and drinks and has been in this business for a long time. With this combined businesses, she is able to provide food on her table to feed her immediate family members.

Rita hopes for a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell
